Title: Bulk Mailer Software Buffer Overflow and Race Condition May Let Local Users Obtain Root Level Access
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the 'Bulk Mailer' software.  A local user could obtain root level access on the system.
It is reported that the software contains multiple flaws, including an off by one error, a buffer overflow when appending the local domain, and a /tmp file race condition.
Impact': A local user may be able to modify files with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the system.
Solution: An unofficial patch is available in the Source Message.  There was no official patch available at the time of this entry.

Title: EMU Webmail Server Discloses Files on the Server to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in EMUMAIL's EMU Webmail system.  A remote user can view files located on the server.
The vulnerability reportedly exists in 'emumail.cgi'.  A remote user can use the following type of URL to view files on the system:

xxx/PATH/emumail.cgi?type=FILE%00

No further details were provided.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view files located on the server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (HP Issues Additional Patches) HP/UX Release of Sendmail May Disclose Unauthorized Information to E-mail Users Under Certain Conditions
Description:
HP reported an information disclosure vulnerability in their release of 'sendmail' for HP/UX.  Under certain conditions, a user may receive information from sendmail that the user is not authorized to receive.
In HP's sendmail releases 8.8.6, 8.9.3, and 8.11.1, it is reported that sendmail may mishandle addresses in e-mail queue warning messages that contain sendmail diagnostic codes.  As a result, a user may receive incorrect information that the user is not authorized to view.

This flaw reportedly affects the following versions of sendmail:

- 8.8.6 on HP-UX 10.20 and 11.00,
- 8.9.3 on HP-UX 10.20, 11.00 and 11.11, and
- 8.11.1 (webrelease) on HP-UX 11.00 and 11.11.

The conditions required to trigger this vulnerability were not described.  No futher information was provided regarding the type of information that may be disclosed.
Impact': A user may receive information from sendmail that the user is not authorized to receive.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following additional patches:

10.24, PHNE_26003,
11.04, PHNE_25984,

These patches can be retrieved from the ITRC at www.itrc.hp.com and provide the sendmail(1m) 8.9.3 upgrade.  The webrelease only, however, can be retrieved from:

http://www.software.hp.com/cgi-bin/swdepot_parser.cgi/cgi/displayProductInfo.pl?productNumber=SMAIL811

For information about previously released patches, see the Message History.
Underlying OS Comments: HP 9000 Series 700/800 Servers running HP-UX 10.20, 10.24, 11.00, 11.04, and 11.11

Title: FTGate Mail Server Heap Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the FTGate mail server for Windows.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the server.
Security.NNOV reported that a remote user can use the APOP command to trigger a heap overflow as shown:

APOP USER <BUFFER>

This will apparently cause the FTGateSrv.exe program to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code.

A remote user can also trigger a memory leak by specifying a large number of RCPT TO: lines in an SMTP session.  This will apparently cause the server to consume 100% of CPU resources during and after the attack.

A remote user can also a denial of service condition and lock out POP3 user accounts without having to authenticate.

buggzy is credited with discovering one of the flaws discussed in this report.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions, locking out POP3 user accounts and causing the server to consume 100% of available CPU resources.  A remote user may also be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch (HF1280), available at:

http://www.ftgate.com/knwldgbs/hotfix.htm
http://www.ftgate.com/download/files/Prohf1280.exe

Title: (Vendor Issues Patch) Re: SquirrelMail Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands By Appending Cookie-based Commands to the $THEME Variable
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the SquirrelMail web-based mail server.  An authenticated remote user can cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the server.
It is reported that a valid and authenticated remote user can append $THEME variable with user-supplied commands via cookies.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A valid and authenticated remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the server with the privileges of the web server.
Solution: The vendor has fixed the code in the current CVS and plans to issue a fixed version (1.2.6) shortly.  The vendor has also supplied a patch, available in the Source Message.

Title: Microsoft Outlook Web Access With SecurID Authentication May Allow Remote Users to Avoid the SecurID Authentication in Certain Cases
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Outlook Web Access (OWA) when used with RSA's SecurID authentication tokens.  In certain cases, a remote user with a valid OWA password can avoid using their SecurID password.
It is reported that a remote user that is authenticated using both the SecurID token and the OWA password can disconnect and then attempt to reconnect using a different OWA account.  This will apparently yield an error page that indicates the following:

"Your NT username (xxxxx) does not match your SecurID username (yyyyy)."

If the user reloads this error page multiple times, the user will eventually gain access to the mailbox of user 'xxxxx' using the appropriate OWA password but without having to authenticate with SecurID password for the 'xxxxx' user.

Both Microsoft and RSA have reportedly been notified.
Impact': In a certain situation, a valid and authenticated remote user can access another user's OWA account by supplying the other user's OWA password but without having to supply the other user's SecurID password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: SquirrelMail Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands By Appending Cookie-based Commands to the $THEME Variable
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the SquirrelMail web-based mail server.  An authenticated remote user can cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the server.
It is reported that a valid and authenticated remote user can append $THEME variable with user-supplied commands via cookies.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A valid and authenticated remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the server with the privileges of the web server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Lotus Domino Mail Server Can Be Made to Consume 100% of CPU Resources By Remote Users
Version(s): R4.63, R5.01, R5.05 and R5.08; possibly others
Description:
A mail processing vulnerability was reported in Lotus Domino.  A remote user can craft a special SMTP message that will cause an endless processing loop that will cause all CPU resources to be consumed on the mail server.
A remote user can send the following type of SMTP message to a Lotus Domino server, where domain.com is a non-local domain, causing the mail server to bounce the message to the local interface (i.e., to itself):

MAIL FROM:<bounce@[127.0.0.1]>
RCPT TO:<address@domain.com>

It is reported that shutting down the mail server, deleting the offending message from the mail queue, and restarting the server will correct the condition.
Impact': A remote user can send a special SMTP message that will cause the mail server to bounce the message to itself, causing an endless processing loop that will result in 100% CPU utilization.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and described a workaround.  This vulnerability has reportedly been corrected in Domino 5.0.9.

To avoid this issue in Domino 5.0.8 and earlier, do the following:

     1. Add "[127.0.0.1]" (without the quotation marks) to the "Deny messages from the following internet addresses/domains" field (in the Server Configuration document's Router/SMTP, Restrictions and Controls, and SMTP Inbound Controls tabs, and Inbound Sender Controls section).  This configuration causes the SMTP Listener task to reject MAIL FROM commands that contain the "[127.0.0.1]" IP address. 

2. Configure the SMTP inbound relay restrictions. If applicable, add the wildcard character "*" to the "Deny messages from external internet domains to be sent to the following internet domains" (in the Server Configuration document's Router/SMTP, Restrictions and Controls, and SMTP Inbound Controls tabs, and Inbound Relay Controls section).  This configuration causes the SMTP Listener task to reject RCPT TO commands that contain external Internet domains, domains not configured through the "Fully qualified Internet host name field" in the Basics tab of the Server document or in the Conversions tab of the Global Domain document(s). This restriction includes the "[127.0.0.1]" IP address.

See the Vendor URL for additional information, including some screen shots showing the appropriate configuration parameters.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Ecartis (Listar) Mailing List Management Software Has Multiple Vulnerabilities That Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Privileges on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Ecartis (Listar) mailing list management software.  A remote user could obtain root level access on the system
It is reported that a buffer overflow in the address_match() function, which handles comparisons between address received in the From header with addresses in the local subscribers database, may allow a remote user to create a specially crafted From header to execute execute arbitrary code on system running the list manager.

It is also reported that Ecartis may fail to drop elevated privileges when executed by a non-privileged user.  According to the report, working privileges are dropped correcly only when Ecartis is called and installed with root privileges and the "lock-to-user" configuration option is set. If the "lock-to-user" configuration option is not set, Ecartis reportedly displays a warning message but continues to work with full root privileges.

It is reported that Ecartis/Listar contain numerous other buffer overflow and other vulnerabilities that were not described in the report.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system with root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for Debian GNU/Linux 2.2 alias potato:

Title: Qualcomm Qpopper E-mail Server Denial of Service Bug Lets Remote Users Crash the POP3 Server
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Qualcomm's Qpopper POP3 e-mail server.  A remote user can cause the POP3 service to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send a string with 2048+ characters to the in.qpopper or popper process to cause the service to consume a large amount of CPU resources until the process is killed.
Impact': A remote user can cause the POP3 service to consume large amounts of CPU resources and hang until the process is killed.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Ecartis (Listar) Mailing List Management Software Has Multiple Vulnerabilities That Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Privileges on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Ecartis (Listar) mailing list management software.  A remote user could obtain root level access on the system
It is reported that a buffer overflow in the address_match() function, which handles comparisons between address received in the From header with addresses in the local subscribers database, may allow a remote user to create a specially crafted From header to execute execute arbitrary code on system running the list manager.

It is also reported that Ecartis may fail to drop elevated privileges when executed by a non-privileged user.  According to the report, working privileges are dropped correcly only when Ecartis is called and installed with root privileges and the "lock-to-user" configuration option is set. If the "lock-to-user" configuration option is not set, Ecartis reportedly displays a warning message but continues to work with full root privileges.

It is reported that Ecartis/Listar contain numerous other buffer overflow and other vulnerabilities that were not described in the report.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system with root privileges.
Solution:
To correct the address_match() buffer overflow, upgrade to Ecartis 1.0.0 snapshot 20020110 or a more recent version.

No vendor solution was available to correct the other reported issues at the time of this entry.

Title: Ipswitch IMail Server Discloses Authentication Tokens to Remote Users Letting Remote Users Access Other User Accounts
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Ipswitch's IMail server.  A remote user can access another IMail user's account.
Eye on Security reported a vulnerability in IMail.  A remote user can send an HTML e-mail message to a target (victim) user that contains an image located on another server.  Then, when the target user receives the message, the target user's web browser will retrieve the image and provide the referring URL.  The referring URL will contain a session authentication code from the IMail server.  This URL can be used to access the target user's account.
Impact': A remote user can access another user's e-mail account.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix (7.06).  This version reportedly checks to ensure that the unique URL (including a session authentication ID) and the IP address are valid.

Title: (A User Provides Exploit Information) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 and Windows XP SMTP Service Command Processing Bug Lets Remote Users Cause the SMTP Service to Crash
Description:
Microsoft issued a security bulletin (MS02-12) warning of a denial of service vulnerabiltiy in the Windows 2000 and XP SMTP services.  A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.
In the original alert, it was reported that the Windows SMTP service contains a flaw in the processing of a specific SMTP command used to transfer incoming mail data. A remote user could send a malformed version of this command to cause the SMTP service to fail. Exchange 2000 reportedly uses the Windows 2000 SMTP service and, therefore, is affected by this vulnerability. The SMTP service is apparently installed by default as part of Windows 2000 Server products but is not installed by default on Windows 2000 and Windows XP Workstation products. Microsoft reports that Exchange 5.5, even if installed on a Windows 2000 server, is not affected by the vulnerability. Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a maximum severity rating of "Low". 

A user (who apparently also is responsible for discovering the bug) has provided a URL that links to demonstration exploit code:

http://www.digitaloffense.net/mssmtp/mssmtp_dos.pl

The BDAT command can reportedly be used to trigger the vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Windows 2000 Server, Professional and Advanced Server:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=36556 

For Windows XP Professional:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=36636 

Microsoft reports that the Windows 2000 patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP2 and the Windows XP patch can be installed on Windows XP Professional Gold.

The fix for this issue will reportedly be included in Windows 2000 SP3 and Windows XP Professional SP1.

Title: SH39 MailServer Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the SMTP Mail Service
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in SH39's MailServer.  A remote user can cause the server to crash.
It is reported that MailServer contains a buffer overflow that can be triggered by a remote user sending a large string (~2500 characters) to the server on port 25.  A remote user can cause the server to crash.  On Windows XP, this will cause the MailServer process to crash.  On Windows 2000, this will cause the SMTP port to stop responding, requiring a MailServer restart to return to normal operations.

The report notes that the software runs with administrative privileges.  However, remote code execution was not reported.
Impact': A remote user can cause the MailServer service to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.22), available at:

http://sh39.net/

Title: Endymion's Sake Mail Web Mail Java Servet Lets Remote Users View Files on the Server
Description:
An input validation flaw was reported in Endymion's Sake Mail web-based mail Java servet. A remote user can view files on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can supply an HTTP request to the server with a relative path ending with a null byte to view the relative path contents.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view files located anywhere on the system that are accessible to the Sake Mail servlet.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Endymion's MailMan Web Mail Server Lets Remote Users View Files on the Server
Description:
An input validation flaw was reported in Endymion's MailMain web-based mail server.  A remote user can view files on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can supply an HTTP request to the 'mmstdo*.cgi' with a relative path ending with a null byte to view the relative path contents:

http://hostname/cgi-bin/mmstdo*.cgi
with the following parameters:
USERNAME=
PASSWORD=
ALTERNATE_TEMPLATES= [relative FILE/PATH] [Nullbyte/0x00]

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view files located anywhere on the system that are accessible to the MailMan cgi.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: AeroMail Web Mail System Lets Remote Users Steal the Cookies of AeroMail Users and Lets Valid Remote Users Access Files on the AeroMail Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the AeroMail PHP-based web mail system.  A remote user with a valid account and authenticated access can retrieve files from the web server.  A remote user can cause malicious Javascript to be executed by the recipient's web browser to steal the recipient's cookies.
It is reported that, when sending an e-mail via the AeroMail system, a remote user with a valid account and authenticated access to the system can reportedly trick the attachment subsystem into sending local files from the web server (or remote files from URL's) instead of the genuine uploaded files.

A demonstration exploit script for this vulnerability is provided in the Source Message (it is a compressed and encoded file).

It is also reported that a remote user can create a special e-mail message that contains malicious Javascript so that when the recipient's AeroMail system displays the Subject field, the code will be executed.  This code will run in the security context of the AeroMail server and will be able to access the recipient's cookies associated with the server.
Impact':
A remote user with a valid account and authenticated access can retrieve files from the web server.

A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against AeroMail users.  Any remote user can cause malicious Javascript to be executed by the recipient's web browser to steal the recipient's cookies.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.45), available at:

http://the.cushman.net/projects/aeromail/download/aeromail-1.45.zip
http://the.cushman.net/projects/aeromail/download/aeromail-1.45.tar.gz

Impact': A remote user can provide a specially crafted command that could cause shell commands to be executed by the server with the privileges of the SASL server.

Title: Microsoft Exchange Server 2000 Command Processing Bug Lets Remote Users Cause the SMTP Service to Crash
Description:
Microsoft issued a security bulletin (MS02-12) warning of a denial of service vulnerabiltiy in the Exchange 2000 mail server. A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.
It is reported that the Windows SMTP service (which is used by Exchange 2000) contains a flaw in the processing of a specific SMTP command used to transfer incoming mail data. A remote user could send a malformed version of this command to cause the SMTP service to fail.

Microsoft reports that Exchange 5.5, even if installed on a Windows 2000 server, is not affected by the vulnerability.

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a maximum severity rating of "Low".
Impact': A remote user can cause the Exchange 2000 SMTP service to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Windows 2000 Server, Professional and Advanced Server:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=36556 

Microsoft reports that the Windows 2000 patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP2.

The fix for this issue will reportedly be included in Windows 2000 SP3.

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 and Windows XP SMTP Service Command Processing Bug Lets Remote Users Cause the SMTP Service to Crash
Description:
Microsoft issued a security bulletin (MS02-12) warning of a denial of service vulnerabiltiy in the Windows 2000 and XP SMTP services.  A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.
It is reported that the Windows SMTP service contains a flaw in the processing of a specific SMTP command used to transfer incoming mail data.  A remote user could send a malformed version of this command to cause the SMTP service to fail.

Exchange 2000 reportedly uses the Windows 2000 SMTP service and, therefore, is affected by this vulnerability.

The SMTP service is apparently installed by default as part of Windows 2000 Server products but is not installed by default on Windows 2000 and Windows XP Workstation products.

Microsoft reports that Exchange 5.5, even if installed on a Windows 2000 server, is not affected by the vulnerability.

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a maximum severity rating of "Low".
Impact': A remote user can cause the SMTP service to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Windows 2000 Server, Professional and Advanced Server:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=36556 

For Windows XP Professional:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=36636 

Microsoft reports that the Windows 2000 patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP2 and the Windows XP patch can be installed on Windows XP Professional Gold.

The fix for this issue will reportedly be included in Windows 2000 SP3 and Windows XP Professional SP1.

Title: Microsoft Exchange Server Lets Remote Users Send or Relay Unauthorized Mail (including SPAM) Via the Server
Description:
Microsoft issued a security bulletin (MS02-11) warning of a vulnerability in the Windows 2000 SMTP service and in Exchange Server 5.5.  A remote user could relay unauthorized mail via the system.
It is reported that the SMTP service that is part of the Internet Mail Connector (IMC) for Microsoft Exchange Server 5.5, sometimes also also known as the Microsoft Exchange Internet Mail Service, contains a vulnerability in the processing of valid responses from the NTLM authentication layer of the underlying operating system.

The Exchange Server 5.5 IMC, upon receiving notification from the NTLM authentication layer that a user has been authenticated, reportedly fail to perform the required additional checks before granting the user access to the service.  In most cases, a remote user that can successfully authenticate to the server can gain access to the SMTP service.

Microsoft reports that Exchange 2000 servers are not affected.

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a maximum severity rating of "Low".
Impact': A remote user that can successfully authenticate to the server can gain access to the SMTP service and, for example, send or relay mail via the server.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.  In April 2004, the vendor added a fix for Windows NT 4.0.  Shown below is the fix for Exchange, as well the fixes for Windows 2000 and NT 4.0 which are affected by the same vulnerability [a separate Alert has been issued regarding the Windows 2000 and NT 4.0].

Windows 2000 Server, Professional and Advanced Server:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID= 36556

Windows NT Server 4.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=457C0C18-8C3E-4923-B395-614C117F13C5&displaylang=en

Exchange Server 5.5:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=33423 

Windows 2000 Datacenter Server:

Patches for Windows 2000 Datacenter Server are hardware-specific and available from the original equipment manufacturer, the vendor said.

The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on Windows 2000 SP1, the Windows NT Server 4.0 patch can be installed on Windows NT Server 4.0 SP6a, and the Exchange Server 5.5 patch can be installed on Exchange Server 5.5 SP4.

This fix will be included in Windows 2000 SP3.

A reboot is required after installing this patch.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Autoresponder Software from MeepZor Consulting Allows Remote Users to Send SPAM Via Accounts Using the Autoresponder in a Certain Configuration
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in MeepZor Consulting's Autoresponder automated e-mail response software.  A remote user can take advantage of another e-mail account that uses Autoresponder in a certain configuration to relay SPAM.
It is reported that if the option to reply with a copy of the original message attached to the response is enabled in autoresponder's configuration, a remote user can use the e-mail account for relaying SPAM.  Autoresponder apparently does not limit the number of auto-replies generated over a period of time.
Impact': A remote user can relay SPAM via an e-mail account that uses Autoresponder in a certain configuration.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.  Download version 1.15.2, available at:

http://MeepZor.Com/packages/autoresponder/

Title: Microsoft Outlook Web Access Discloses 'Include' Archive Files in the 'lib' Directory to Remote Users
Description:
Aris Telecom issued an advisory warning of an information disclosure vulnerability in Outlook Web Access. A remote user can view certain 'include' archive files on the system.
It is reported that a remote user can view all the archives of the 'lib' directory. These archives are reportedly stored with the '.INC' extension. A remote user can request the following type of URL to view the files: 

http://[targethost]/exchange/lib/logon.inc 

It is reported that the following additional archives can also be viewed: 

  exchange/lib/AMPROPS.INC 
  exchange/lib/ATTACH.INC 
  exchange/lib/DELETE.INC 
  exchange/lib/GETREND.INC 
  exchange/lib/GETWHEN.INC 
  exchange/lib/JSATTACH.INC 
  exchange/lib/JSROOT.INC 
  exchange/lib/JSUTIL.INC 
  exchange/lib/LANG.INC 
  exchange/lib/PAGEUTIL.INC 
  exchange/lib/PUBFLD.INC 
  exchange/lib/RENDER.INC 
  exchange/lib/SESSION.INC 
  exchange/lib/STORE.INC 

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view certain source code include file archives on the server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Potential Bug in Exim Mail Server May Let Local Users Execute Code With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A potential buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Exim mail server.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges, but that has not been confirmed by the author of the report.
It is reported that a local user can invoke certain exim options to trigger a segmentation fault, such as the following:

/usr/exim/bin/exim -F `perl -e' print "A" x 32770'` -C `perl -e' print "A" x 32768'`
Segmentation fault

Other arguments may result in similar results (as long there is -C among them), according the report.

It is reported that the above command line does not overwrite the EIP register.  However, the author of the report believes that there may be a way to exploit this bug with the log_write() functionn to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the server with root privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges, but that has not been confirmed.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided a patch to version 3.34, availale in the Source Message.

[Editor's Note:  This patch is not an official patch and it has not been confirmed to fix the flaw.]

Title: NetWin CWMail Web-Mail Server Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the System With the Privileges of the IIS Web Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
NGSSoftware reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in NetWin's CWMail web-mail server.
It is reported that the CWMail.exe executable for Windows-based servers has a buffer overflow in its processing of the 'item=' field when forwarding mail.  A remote user can fill this field with a large string of characters to trigger the flaw, potentially causing arbitrary code to be executed.  The code would be executed with the privileges of the web server.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the web-mail server with the privileges of the web server.  Depending on the web server configuration, this may be System level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch, available at:

http://netwinsite.com/dmailweb/download2.htm

Title: IceWarp Web Mail Lets Remote Users Steal User Session IDs and Access Mail Accounts Belonging to Other Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IceWarp Web Mail.  A remote user can obtain a session ID belonging to another user and can then access that other user's e-mail.
It is reported that when a new user is created, IceWarp assigns the new user a static identity number.  If the new user does not logout after checking for mail, a remote user can access the mail box.

For example, if the user's static number is '098d0f444ec627534540ac4f02f29fh7', a remote user can access the inbox with the following type of URL if the session timeout has not yet occurred:

http://[targethost]/view.html?id=098d0f444c627534540ac4f02f29fh7

It is reported that the static ID never changes.  It is also reported that a user's static ID is disclosed when sending mail to other e-mail account on the same IceWarp system.
Impact': A remote user can access an IceWarp user's mail account in certain situations.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report recommends modifying settings in 'include.html' to make the default value of 240 minutes a lower timeout value.

Title: Microsoft Exchange 2000 Server Allows Remote Users to View and Possibly Modify Registry Settings
Description:
Microsoft reported a vulnerability in Microsoft Exchange 2000 in the Microsoft Exchange System Attendant core component.  A remote user can view the registry and may be able to make changes to the registry.
It is reported that the Microsoft Exchange System Attendant is designed to make changes to permissions on the Windows Registry to allow Exchange Administrators to remotely update Registry configuration settings.  According to the vendor, the System Attendant contains a flaw that could allow a remote user to access configuration information on the server. 

This flaw apparently gives the "Everyone" group privileges to access the WinReg key, which controls the ability of users and groups to remotely connect to the Registry.  Only Administrators should be given this ability (in a default configuration).  The key is located at:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurePipeServers\winreg

Microsoft reports that it may be possible for the remote user to make changes to the Registry, depending on the permissions of the specific keys within the Registry itself.

To exploit this flaw, the remote user must be able to send SMB traffic to and from the target server. 

Microsoft assigns this vulnerability a "low" risk rating for Internet and Intranet servers.

Microsoft credits Eitan Caspi for reporting this issue.
Impact': A remote user can view registry settings.  A remote user may be able to modify registry settings.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  Patches for Microsoft Exchange Server 2000 are available at:           
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/release.asp?ReleaseID=35462 

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Microsoft Exchange 2000 SP2.  The vendor plans to include this fix in Microsoft Exchange 2000 SP3.

Title: SquirrelMail Web-based Mail Server Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in SquirrelMail webmail server.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the server.
It is reported that the spell checker plugin (check_me.mod.php) allows a remote user to specify commands to be executed on the server. The following type of URL will reportedly trigger the vulnerability:

host/plugins/squirrelspell/modules/check_me.mod.php?SQSPELL_APP[blah]=wall%
20hello&sqspell_use_app=blah&attachment_dir=/tmp&username_sqspell_data=plik
Impact': A remote user can execute commands on the server with the privileges of the web server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.2.4), available at:

http://www.squirrelmail.org/download.php

Also, the following patch for 1.2.2 was supplied by a user:

http://www.dulug.duke.edu/~icon/misc/security_fix.sh.txt

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Exim Mail Server Pipe Address Validation Error May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges in a Certain Configuration
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): prior to Exim 3.34 and Exim 3.952 (alpha for Exim 4)
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Exim mail server.  In a certain configuration, a remote user could cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the server with root level privileges, giving the user root level access on the server.
A remote user may be able to execute shell commands on the server if the server is configured in a specific manner.  In a run time configuration that directs or routes an address to a pipe transport without checking the local part of the address in any way, the system may be vulnerable.  An example of this type of configuration is where all incoming mail is sent directly to a virus checker by means of a pipe, without inspecting the local parts of addresses.

The bug can reportedly be triggered by routing/directing an address whose local part begins with a pipe symbol (vertical bar, "|") to a pipe transport.  As a result, Exim will run the command encoded in the local part instead of obeying the pipe command.

The author of the report notes that Patrice Fournier discovered and reported the problem.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands on the server with root level privileges if the server is configured in a particular manner.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix and recommends that all Exim users upgrade their packages.

Title: Mailidx Perl-based Mailbox Front End Allows Remote Users to Execute SQL Commands on the Underlying SQL Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mailidx Perl-based CGI front end for a UNIX mailbox.  A remote user can inject SQL commands that will be executed by the underlying SQL server.
It is reported that the script does not implement sufficient input validation on the search page.
Impact': A remote user can execute SQL commands on the underlying database with the ability to view, modify, or delete database entries.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (20020105), available at:

http://freshmeat.net/redir/mailidx/18105/url_tgz/mailidx-20020105.tar.gz

Title: HP/UX Release of Sendmail May Disclose Unauthorized Information to E-mail Users Under Certain Conditions
Description:
HP reported an information disclosure vulnerability in their release of 'sendmail' for HP/UX.  Under certain conditions, a user may receive information from sendmail that the user is not authorized to receive.
In HP's sendmail releases 8.8.6, 8.9.3, and 8.11.1, it is reported that sendmail may mishandle addresses in e-mail queue warning messages that contain sendmail diagnostic codes.  As a result, a user may receive incorrect information that the user is not authorized to view.

This flaw reportedly affects the following versions of sendmail:

- 8.8.6 on HP-UX 10.20 and 11.00,
- 8.9.3 on HP-UX 10.20, 11.00 and 11.11, and
- 8.11.1 (webrelease) on HP-UX 11.00 and 11.11.

The conditions required to trigger this vulnerability were not described.  No futher information was provided regarding the type of information that may be disclosed.
Impact': A user may receive information from sendmail that the user is not authorized to receive.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches:

10.20,             PHNE_25183
11.00,             PHNE_24419
11.00,             sendmail 8.11.1 web release upgrade
11.11,             PHNE_25184
11.11,             sendmail 8.11.1 web release upgrade

These patches can be retrieved from the ITRC at http://www.itrc.hp.com.  The webrelease only can be retrieved from:

      http://www.software.hp.com/cgi-bin/swdepot_parser.cgi/cgi/
      displayProductInfo.pl?productNumber=SMAIL811
Underlying OS Comments: HP 9000 Series 700/800 Servers running HP-UX 10.20, 11.00, and 11.11.

Title: Procmail E-mail Sanitizer May Fail to Filter Certain Messages Containing Recursive MIME Parts
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Procmail E-mail Sanitizer.  A remote user can send mail that bypasses the filtering mechanism.
It is reported that the software does not properly handling some recursive multipart MIME messages.  Some malicious code can avoid the sanitization/filtering mechanism.
Impact': A remote user can send e-mail containing malicious code through the sanitizer without being completely filtered.
Solution:
Upgrade to version 1.133, available at:

http://www.impsec.org/email-tools/sanitizer-download.html

Title: Autoresponder Software from MeepZor Consulting Allows Remote Users to Send SPAM Via Accounts Using the Autoresponder in a Certain Configuration
Description:

It is reported that if the option to reply with a copy of the original message attached to the response is enabled in autoresponder's configuration, a remote user can use the e-mail account for relaying SPAM.  Autoresponder apparently does not limit the number of auto-replies generated over a period of time.

Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Address.com Hosted E-mail Service Bug Lets Remote Users Take Over Another User's E-mail Account and View the Previous User's Stored E-mail Messages
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Address.com hosted e-mail service.  A remote user can hijack another user's account, view the stored messages, and lock out the legitimate user.
It is reported that the Address.com hosted e-mail registration process allows a remote user to overwrite existing accounts.  If successful, the password is apparently overwritten and the new user takes full control of the account.  It is also reported that the e-mail messages of the former user remain accessible to the new user.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can take over another user's e-mail account, preventing the other user from accessing their account.  The remote user can view any stored messages on the hijacked account.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Exim Mail Server Pipe Address Validation Error May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges in a Certain Configuration
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): prior to Exim 3.34 and Exim 3.952 (alpha for Exim 4)
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Exim mail server.  In a certain configuration, a remote user could cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the server with root level privileges, giving the user root level access on the server.
A remote user may be able to execute shell commands on the server if the server is configured in a specific manner.  In a run time configuration that directs or routes an address to a pipe transport without checking the local part of the address in any way, the system may be vulnerable.  An example of this type of configuration is where all incoming mail is sent directly to a virus checker by means of a pipe, without inspecting the local parts of addresses.

Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands on the server with root level privileges if the server is configured in a particular manner.

Title: Ipswitch IMail Server Access Control Flaw Lets Remote Administrators for One Hosted Domain Access Administrator Functions for a Different Hosted Domain
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Ipswitch's IMail server.  A remote user with administrative privileges may access administrative functions of a different hosted domain's web mail service.
A remote user with administrative privileges for one hosted domain may access the "Alias" and "List" administration controls of another hosted domain if the IMail server has multiple hosted domains.

It is reported that IMail only validates to determine if the remote user has administrative privileges in their domain and does not determine if the remote user is an administrator within the current domain.  As a result, the remote user can list, view, add, edit, or delete the user aliases and mailing lists of the current domain.

Demonstration exploit transcripts are provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user with administrative users in one domain can access the user aliases and mailing list administrative functions in a different domain.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Fix Has Been Available Since June 2001) Re: Perdition E-mail Gateway Format String Bug Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with Root Privileges and Gain Root Access to the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
GOBBLES Labs reported a format string vulnerability in the Perdition POP/IMAP retrieval gateway.  A remote user can obtain root access on the server.
It is reported that a format string bug resides in the libvanessa_logger library used by Perdition, part of the FreeBSD Ports Collection. A remote user can apparently supply input containing a format string that will be executed by a syslog() call.  The daemon reportedly runs with root level privileges, so the remotely supplied commands will be executed with root privileges.
Impact': A remote user can execute commands on the server with root level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor reports that vanessa_logger 0.0.2, released on the 29th of June 2001, is not vulnerable and that FreeBSD has released a patched version of vanessa_logger 0.0.1 which is also not vulnerable.

vanessa_logger 0.0.2 is available at:

ftp://ftp.vergenet.net/pub/vanessa/vanessa_logger/0.0.2

The vendor also recommends that users run perdition as a non-root user. The --username and --group options enable perdition to run as non-root for most of a processes life. If these options are used then the potential risk from any exploits stemming from the string format bug in vanessa_logger are significantly reduced, according to the vendor.

Title: (HP Issues Fix for HP Secure OS for Linux) Sendmail Command Line Debugging Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
SecurityFocus discovered an input validation vulnerability in the Sendmail '-d' debugging facility that allows a local user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a flaw in the use of signed integers in Sendmail's tTflag() debugging function.

A remote user can call sendmail with the '-d' command line switch and can supply a large value for the 'category' part of the arguments to be used as an index for the system's internal trace vector.  The user-supplied arguments can apparently cause a signed integer overflow such that the input validation function does not detect that the size of the user-supplied trace vector data exceeds the indicated (and overflowed) length value.  

It is reported that the trace vector data is written before the program drops its set user id (suid) root privileges.  As a result, a local user can overwrite process memory and cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
Impact': A local user can invoke sendmail and cause arbitrary code to be executed with root level privileges, giving the user root level access on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for HP Secure OS for Linux in hplx-sendmail-1.1-1, which is based upon Sendmail v8.12.1.

Apply the following patch:

        HPTL_00007

To obtain the patch, use your browser to access the HP IT Resource Center page at:

       http://itrc.hp.com

Use the 'Login' tab at the left side of the screen to login using your ID and password.  Use your existing login or the "Register" button at the left to create a login. Remember to save the User ID assigned to you, and your password. This login provides access to many useful areas of the ITRC.

Under the "Maintenance and Support" section, select "Individual Patches".

In the field at the bottom of the page labeled "retrieve a specific patch by entering the patch name", enter {{ Patch number (s) }}

For instructions on installing the patch, please see the install text file included in the patch.

Title: Qualcomm's Eudora Qpopper 'popauth' Module Symlink Bug May Let Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A file symlink vulnerability was reported in Qpopper.  A local user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed with set user id (suid) 'pop' user privileges.
It is reported that popauth is often istalled with suid pop permissions and also will follow symbolic links when executed with the -trace command line option.  A local user can create a symlink that will execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the 'pop' user when another user sets their userid to 'pop'.

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user could cause arbitary code to be executed with 'pop' user privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Description:

It is reported that there is a hidden directory that provides access to an administrator menu.  No authentication is required.

The following type of URL will apparently provide access:

http://target/a/

Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report recommends using web server access control methods (e.g., .htaccess) to protect access to this hidden administrator URL.

Title: Microsoft Outlook Web Access for Exchange May Execute Remotely Supplied Scripts When a Recipient Views a Malicious E-mail Message
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Outlook Web Access using Microsoft  Exchange 5.5 Server
Description:
Microsoft reported that WhiteHat Security discovered a flaw in Outlook Web Access (OWA).  A remote user could cause arbitrary code to be executed by an OWA user's browser when the OWA user views a malicious e-mail.
A flaw reportedly exists in the way OWA, in conjunction with Internet Explorer, handles inline scripts in HTML-based e-mail messages. A remote user can create a specially crafted HTML-based message that contains a specially formatted script in the body of the message so that when the the message is opened in OWA, the script will execute on the recipient's browser.

The script can apparently take any action against the user's Exchange mailbox that the user himself is capable of, including sending, moving, or deleting messages.
Impact': A remote user can create an HTML-based e-mail message that will, when viewed by an OWA user, cause arbitrary code to be executed by the OWA recipient.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch for Microsoft Exchange 5.5:

            http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=34402 

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Exchange 5.5 SP4.  To install successfully, this patch requires that the OWA server have IE 5.0 or greater installed. At the time of this writing, the following versions are recommended for dependent components on the OWA server: 

IIS Version 4.0 on Windows NT 4.0 SP5 or greater 
IIS Version 5.0 on Windows 2000 SP1 or greater 

IE Version 5.5 SP2 
IE Version 6.0 

This patch superseded patch MS01-030, which was for a similar but different problem.

To verify that the patch has been installed on the machine, confirm that the following registry key has been created on the machine: 

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Updates\Exchange Server 5.5\SP5\Q313576.

Title: Fml Mailing List Archive Application Does Not Escape Certain User Input, Allowing Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Debian reported a security vulnerability in the fml mailing list application.  The server does not filter out HTML characters and is vulnerable to cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that fml, as distributed in Debian GNU/Linux 2.2 (and possibly other distributions), allows cross-site scripting attacks. When the application generates index pages for list archives, it fails to escape the `<' and `>' characters in the e-mail subject field.

A remote user can create an e-mail that contains a subject field with embedded HTML code with Javascript.  When another user views the archive containing that e-mail message, the Javascript code may be executed by that user's browser.  The Javascript code will appear to originate from the server running the fml mailing list archive, which may be a server that the user's browser trusts.  The Javascript code could potentially access the user's cookies or other sensitive information related to that server.
Impact': A remote user can conduct a cross-site scripting attack against another user by using the fml mailing list archive server.
Solution:
For Debian Linxu, this has been fixed in version 3.0+beta.20000106-5 and Debian recommends that customers upgrade their fml package to that version. Upgrading will reportedly regenerate the archive index pages automatically.

Title: (SGI Describes Workaround) Re: Sendmail Security Holes Let Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges on the System, Access the E-mail Queue, and Cause Information Loss
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
BindView's RAZOR security team warned of multiple vulnerabilities in Sendmail.  The security holes allow a local user to obtain elevated privileges on the system.
Several vulnerabilities were reported:

1) It is reported that a programming error in version 8.12.0 caused Sendmail to fail to drop extra privileges and run at the user level when processing untrusted, user-supplied configurations.  The software reportedly retains the saved group id (gid) of 'smmsp'.  A local user can call the setregid() function to regain these 'dropped' privileges.  To do this, the local user must take control of Sendmail.  RAZOR reports tht that can be done by exploiting various aspects of the configuration file parsing code, as described in the Source Message.

Once the local user has gained control of the Sendmail process, the local user can issue the setregid() system call and gain smmsp group access permissions.  With these group privileges, the local user can access and modify the user-level queue (/var/spool/clientmqueue), reading or modifying the mail of other users.  It may also be possible to obtain elevated privileges (root level group id of "0") via methods vaguely described in the Source Message.

2) It is reported that a programming bug in Sendmail allows a local user to specify mail delivery options that will be inadvertently processed by Sendmail.  For example, the local user can force Sendmail to drop queue contents by setting initial message hop count above the limit with the following command:

sendmail -q -h1000

Specific queue entries can apparently be targeted using parameters such as -qR and -qS.  This can lead to data loss.

Sendmail systems that do not permit users to run the queue (RestrictQRun option) are not affected by this vulnerability.

3) Information may reportedly be leaked in debug mode.  A local user can use debugging flags to obtain the complete mail system configuration and gather potentially sensitive information about the mail queue (e.g., full message path, subject, mail software), such as with the following command:

    sendmail -q -d0-nnnn.xxx

where nnnn and xxx specify debugging levels.

It is reported that Sendmail systems that do not allow users to run the queue (RestrictQRun option) are not affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user could gain elevated privileges ('smmsp' group privileges) and access the client mail queue.  A local user can cause Sendmail to drop queue contents.  A local user can also gain information about the sendmail configuration.
Solution:
Currently, there are no patches available from SGI to address these issues.  SGI recommends the following steps to disable users from being able to run the queue:

     1) Become the root user on the system.

                % /bin/su -
                Password:
                #

     2) Edit the file /etc/sendmail.mc

                # vi  /etc/sendmail.mc

       {Add the following line}

       define(`confPRIVACY_FLAGS', `restrictqrun')dnl

       {Save the file and exit}


     3) Rebuild the sendmail.cf file from the modified
        sendmail.mc file.

                # /usr/etc/configmail mc2cf


     4) Stop and restart sendmail

                # /etc/init.d/mail stop
                # /etc/init.d/mail start


     5) Return to previous level.

                # exit
                %
Underlying OS Comments: All versions of IRIX are vulnerable

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Postfix Mail Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Initiating Unsuccessful Sessions

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Horde Internet Messaging Program (IMP) Cross-Site Scripting Flaw Lets Remote Users Steal Session Cookies and Hijack E-mail Sessions
Description:
A cross-site scripting vulnerability has been reported in the Horde Project Internet Messaging Program (IMP).  A remote user can potentially hijack an IMP session.
It is reported that a remote user can create a malicious HTML-based e-mail message such that, when the message is viewed, arbitrary code is executed by the target user's browser.  The code will appear to originate from the mail server and will be able to access the user's web mail cookies and forward those cookies to another location.

After obtaining the cookies, the remote user can then hijack the session and read the target user's email.

It is reported that the development version 2.3 and 3.0 Release Candidate 1 are not affected by this vulnerability.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can hijack another user's email session.
Solution:
The vendor has released version 2.2.7 and recommends that all sites running IMP 2.2.x upgrade to this version.

This release can be downloaded from the following locations:

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Sendmail Security Holes Let Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges on the System, Access the E-mail Queue, and Cause Information Loss
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
BindView's RAZOR security team warned of multiple vulnerabilities in Sendmail.  The security holes allow a local user to obtain elevated privileges on the system.
Several vulnerabilities were reported:

1) It is reported that a programming error in version 8.12.0 caused Sendmail to fail to drop extra privileges and run at the user level when processing untrusted, user-supplied configurations.  The software reportedly retains the saved group id (gid) of 'smmsp'.  A local user can call the setregid() function to regain these 'dropped' privileges.  To do this, the local user must take control of Sendmail.  RAZOR reports tht that can be done by exploiting various aspects of the configuration file parsing code, as described in the Source Message.

Once the local user has gained control of the Sendmail process, the local user can issue the setregid() system call and gain smmsp group access permissions.  With these group privileges, the local user can access and modify the user-level queue (/var/spool/clientmqueue), reading or modifying the mail of other users.  It may also be possible to obtain elevated privileges (root level group id of "0") via methods vaguely described in the Source Message.

2) It is reported that a programming bug in Sendmail allows a local user to specify mail delivery options that will be inadvertently processed by Sendmail.  For example, the local user can force Sendmail to drop queue contents by setting initial message hop count above the limit with the following command:

sendmail -q -h1000

Specific queue entries can apparently be targeted using parameters such as -qR and -qS.  This can lead to data loss.

Sendmail systems that do not permit users to run the queue (RestrictQRun option) are not affected by this vulnerability.

3) Information may reportedly be leaked in debug mode.  A local user can use debugging flags to obtain the complete mail system configuration and gather potentially sensitive information about the mail queue (e.g., full message path, subject, mail software), such as with the following command:

    sendmail -q -d0-nnnn.xxx

where nnnn and xxx specify debugging levels.

It is reported that Sendmail systems that do not allow users to run the queue (RestrictQRun option) are not affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user could gain elevated privileges ('smmsp' group privileges) and access the client mail queue.  A local user can cause Sendmail to drop queue contents.  A local user can also gain information about the sendmail configuration.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

Title: (Caldera Issues Fix for OpenLinux) Sendmail Security Holes Let Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges on the System, Access the E-mail Queue, and Cause Information Loss
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
BindView's RAZOR security team warned of multiple vulnerabilities in Sendmail.  The security holes allow a local user to obtain elevated privileges on the system.
Several vulnerabilities were reported:

1) It is reported that a programming error in version 8.12.0 caused Sendmail to fail to drop extra privileges and run at the user level when processing untrusted, user-supplied configurations.  The software reportedly retains the saved group id (gid) of 'smmsp'.  A local user can call the setregid() function to regain these 'dropped' privileges.  To do this, the local user must take control of Sendmail.  RAZOR reports tht that can be done by exploiting various aspects of the configuration file parsing code, as described in the Source Message.

Once the local user has gained control of the Sendmail process, the local user can issue the setregid() system call and gain smmsp group access permissions.  With these group privileges, the local user can access and modify the user-level queue (/var/spool/clientmqueue), reading or modifying the mail of other users.  It may also be possible to obtain elevated privileges (root level group id of "0") via methods vaguely described in the Source Message.

2) It is reported that a programming bug in Sendmail allows a local user to specify mail delivery options that will be inadvertently processed by Sendmail.  For example, the local user can force Sendmail to drop queue contents by setting initial message hop count above the limit with the following command:

sendmail -q -h1000

Specific queue entries can apparently be targeted using parameters such as -qR and -qS.  This can lead to data loss.

Sendmail systems that do not permit users to run the queue (RestrictQRun option) are not affected by this vulnerability.

3) Information may reportedly be leaked in debug mode.  A local user can use debugging flags to obtain the complete mail system configuration and gather potentially sensitive information about the mail queue (e.g., full message path, subject, mail software), such as with the following command:

    sendmail -q -d0-nnnn.xxx

where nnnn and xxx specify debugging levels.

It is reported that Sendmail systems that do not allow users to run the queue (RestrictQRun option) are not affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user could gain elevated privileges ('smmsp' group privileges) and access the client mail queue.  A local user can cause Sendmail to drop queue contents.  A local user can also gain information about the sendmail configuration.
Solution:
The vendor has described a workaround to fix the issue:

For OpenLinux 2.3, OpenLinux eServer 2.3.1 and OpenLinux eDesktop 2.4:

In /etc/sendmail.cf, change the line:

          O PrivacyOptions=authwarnings

        to read:

          O PrivacyOptions=authwarnings,restrictqrun

For OpenLinux Workstation and Server 3.1:

        In /etc/mail/sendmail.cf, change the line:

          O PrivacyOptions=authwarnings,noexpn,novrfy,noetrn,noverb

        to read:

          O PrivacyOptions=authwarnings,noexpn,novrfy,noetrn,noverb,restrictqrun

Title: Re: Ipswitch's IMail Server POP3 Daemon Discloses Information on Username Validity to Remote Users and Lets Valid Remote Users Change Account Names of Other Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported by ntsecurity.nu in the Ipswitch IMail Server.  The POP3 server provides an indication to remote users as to whether a username is valid or not.  The web messaging interface allows valid and authenticated remote users to change other users' account names.
A user reports that some additional versions are vulnerable (IMail 6.06 5-1 and IMail 6.02 35405-2) and that the problem still continues after patching (IM606hf5.exe) IMail 6.06.

For details on the vulnerability, see the Message History.
Impact': A remote user can determine whether a particular account name exists on the server.  A valid and authenticated remote user can change any other user's accountname, providing a denial of service condition.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly made a patch available at the Vendor URL.

Title: Ipswitch's IMail Server POP3 Daemon Discloses Information on Username Validity to Remote Users and Lets Valid Remote Users Change Account Names of Other Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported by ntsecurity.nu in the Ipswitch IMail Server.  The POP3 server provides an indication to remote users as to whether a username is valid or not.  The web messaging interface allows valid and authenticated remote users to change other users' account names.
One vulnerability was reported with the POP3 server and another with the web interface.

If a remote user supplies a valid username to the POP3 daemon, the server reportedly replies with the following:

+OK welcome

If a remote user supplies an invalid username (i.e., one that does not exist on the server) to the POP3 daemon, the server reportedly replies with the following:

+OK send your password

This information disclosure enables a remote user to probe the server for valid account names.

On the Web Messaging Server, a valid and authenticated remote user can change the user name of another account.  This is possible because the server reportedly trusts the "olduser" hidden HTML INPUT tag in the "Change User Information" web form as being valid.  The remote user can change the "olduser" value and submit the FORM with the malicious value to change the "olduser" account name to a different name.
Impact': A remote user can determine whether a particular account name exists on the server.  A valid and authenticated remote user can change any other user's accountname, providing a denial of service condition.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly made a patch available at the Vendor URL.

Title: Ipswitch's IMail Server Contains Multiple Flaws that Allow Remote Users to Access E-mail Accounts and Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Description:
Several vulnerabilities have been reported in Ipswitch's IMail Server.  Remote users can guess session IDs or hijack e-mail sessions to access user accounts.  Validated and authenticated remote users can access other user e-mail accounts and can cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that IMail uses predictable session IDs that can be feasibly guessed through analysis.  Some example session IDs are provided in the Source Message.

A remote user can hijack an e-mail session if the remote user is able to guess a valid session ID.  The remote user does not need to know any user names or passwords to achieve this.

In addition, a remote user can attempt to obtain a session ID by other means.  Because session IDs are URL based, they could be obtained (for example) by sending  the target user an HTML-based e-mail with an embedded image link.  When the user views the message, the image link will be followed, and the user's web browser will disclose the Session ID via the HTTP Referrer field.  Other methods described in the Source Method are reportedly possible.

A remote but valid and authenticated mail user can gain access to other users' mailboxes by exploiting an input validation flaw and traversing the mailbox directory.  The following type of URL can be used by a valid and authenticated 'user1' to access the main inbox of 'user2':

http://xx.xx.xx.xx:8383/<user1 sessionid>/readmail.cgi?uid=user1&mbx=../user2/Main

Information about the IMail directory structure is reportedly disclosed when a user sends an e-mail.  An example email header is provided:

From: "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX" <XXXXXXXX@XXXXXXXXX>
Reply-To: <XXXXXXXX@XXXXXXXX>
X-Sender: <XXXXXX@XXXXXXXXX>
To: <XXXXXX@XXXXXXXXX>
Subject: Slides
X-Mailer: <IMail v7.04>
X-Attachments: f:\Imail\spool\web\file.zip;
X-Sanitizer: In
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Finally, a valid and authenticated remote user that attempts to open a mailbox which exists out of 248 dot characters will cause the server's web interface to crash.  The process reportedly remains running but will no longer respond to the defined port.
Impact': A remote user can guess predictable session IDs to access e-mail accounts.  A remote user can hijack e-mail sessions to access e-mail accounts.  Validated and authenticated remote users can access other user e-mail accounts.  Validate and authenticated remote users can cause denial of service conditions on the server.  Remote users can obtain information about the IMail directory structure.
Solution:
The user mailbox disclosure vulnerability and the denial of service vulnerability can reportedly be corrected by the Ipswitch hotfix, reportedly available at:

ftp://ftp.ipswitch.com/Ipswitch/Product_Support/IMail/IM704HF1.exe

The session ID guessing and session hijacking vulnerabilities can reportedly be eliminated by deselecting the "ignore source address in security check" option.  This apparently requires all connections to originate from the IP address that was originally authenticated, which may not work in some gateway and proxy situations.

No solution was provided for the e-mail header information disclosure vulnerability.

3) Information may reportedly be leaked in debug mode.  A local user can use debugging flags to obtain the complete mail system configuration and gather potentially sensitive information about the mail queue (e.g., full message path, subject, mail software), such as with the following command:

where nnnn and xxx specify debugging levels.

Solution:
The vendor has released a fix (8.12.1), available from the Vendor URL.  The vendor has also released the following information regarding the fix:

  We would like to thank Michal Zalewski for bringing these problems
  to our attention. We are sorry that these issues haven't been found
  earlier despite extensive beta testing. In response to his advisory
  we will release sendmail 8.12.1 that addresses the issues as follows:

  - For operating systems where the system call setgid() does not
    irrevocably give up privileges obtained via the set-group-ID binary,
    three other options are available: setegid(), setregid(), and
    setresgid(). Additionally sendmail checks whether the privileges
    can be regained when they should have been dropped in which case
    sendmail refuses to run.

  - The PrivacyOptions RestrictQRun is set by default for mail submission
    (submit.cf) to avoid privacy leaks or mail loss due to mailicous
    local users.

  - 8.12.1 prevents information leakage when sendmail has extra
    privileges by disabling debugging (command line -d flag) during queue
    runs and disabling ETRN when sendmail -bs is used.

  - 8.12.1 limits mail submission command line flags (i.e., -G, -h,
    -F, etc.) to mail submission operating modes (i.e., -bm, -bs, -bv,
    etc.) when sendmail is running with extra privileges.

  - Additonal test programs are distributed with sendmail that
    can check whether the required functionality of system calls is
    available. See test/README in 8.12.1 for further information.

  - The potential memory corruption problems have been fixed.

Title: Microsoft Outlook Web Access Directory Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Consume CPU Resources by Requesting Mail from Nested Folders
Version(s): Microsoft Exchange 2000 Server Outlook Web Access
Description:
Microsoft reported a denial of service vulnerability in Exchange 2000 Outlook Web Access (OWA).  A remote user with authenticated and valid access to an OWA mailbox can request a mail message from a sub-folder to make the CPU consume nearly all available CPU resources.
By repeatedly requesting an item from a deeply nested directory within the user's mailbox, a remote user with authenticated and valid access to the mailbox could consume most or all of the CPU availability on the server processing the request.  It is reported that the server processing the request may be the OWA server or a back-end server, depending on the configuration.  Only Exchange servers that host user mailboxes are affected.

The folder does not need to exist for the vulnerability to be triggered.
Impact': A remote user with authenticated and valid access to an OWA mailbox can cause the OWA server or a back-end server to consume most or all available CPU resources on that server.  Once the request has been processed, the affected server would return to normal operation.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch for Microsoft Exchange 2000, available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=32431 

The patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Microsoft Exchange 2000 SP1.  For details on applying and verifying the patch, please read the vendor's advisory (available at the Vendor URL).

The vendor reports that the fix for this vulnerability will be included in Exchange 2000 SP2.

Title: Majordomo Configuration Error Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A configuration error vulnerability was reported in the Majordomo e-mail list management software.  If care is not taken in the default installation of Majordomo, a local user could obtain majordomo privileges on the system.
If majordomo is assigned a home directory (/home/majordomo) and given a shell, the file 'wrapper' will be installed in that directory with set user id (suid) root privileges and with global execution permissions.

A local user can then take advantage of a flaw in ~majordomo/archive2.pl that allows a file to contain '/' characters.  The archive2.pl program can be used to append a malicious file to majordomo's .bash_profile (or .profile) file using the following commands:

echo "ln -s /bin/sh ~/majordomo/sh 2>/dev/null">test 

~majordomo/wrapper archive2.pl -f .bash_profile -a ~marco/test 

Once this has been done, the symbolic link specified in the malicious 'test' file will be created when the .bash_profile is loaded.  Then, any local user can call the wrapper program to obtain a shell with majordomo user privileges and daemon group privileges, as shown in the following exploit transcript:

~majordomo/wrapper sh 
sh-2.05$ id -a 
uid=666(majordomo) gid=2(daemon) groups=100(users) 
sh-2.05$
Impact': A local user can obtain 'majordomo' user privileges and 'daemon' group privileges.
Solution:
It is reported that the INSTALL file contains directions on how to avoid this configuration error.

The author of the report has provided a patch to ensure that the wrapper is not globally executable (giving it 4750 privileges instead of 4755).  The patch is included in the Source Message.
Underlying OS Comments: tested on a Slackware linux 8.0 (kernel 2.4.8); applicable to other operating systems

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Sendmail Command Line Debugging Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): versions between 8.10.0 and 8.11.5 as well as all 8.12.0.Beta versions
Description:
SecurityFocus discovered an input validation vulnerability in the Sendmail '-d' debugging facility that allows a local user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a flaw in the use of signed integers in Sendmail's tTflag() debugging function.

A remote user can call sendmail with the '-d' command line switch and can supply a large value for the 'category' part of the arguments to be used as an index for the system's internal trace vector.  The user-supplied arguments can apparently cause a signed integer overflow such that the input validation function does not detect that the size of the user-supplied trace vector data exceeds the indicated (and overflowed) length value.  

It is reported that the trace vector data is written before the program drops its set user id (suid) root privileges.  As a result, a local user can overwrite process memory and cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.
Impact': A local user can invoke sendmail and cause arbitrary code to be executed with root level privileges, giving the user root level access on the system.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Fetchmail Executes Arbitrary Code Supplied By Remote Servers
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A memory modification vulnerability was reported in Fetchmail, allowing remote users to execute arbitrary code on the fetchmail server in certain situations.
It is reported that flaws in the pop3.c and imap.c files allow a remote user to 'poke' arbitrary memory addresses with 32 bit data. A remote user that is impersonating a POP3 or IMAP server that fetchmail queries can trigger this vulnerability.  If the remote user can spoof the fetchmail server's DNS, then the remote user can potentially trigger the vulnerability without impersonating the POP3 or IMAP mail server.

Some demonstration exploit code is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause fetchmail to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the user account running fetchmail.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: GNU Mailman Mailing List Manager Gives Remote Users Administrative Access When the Global Password is Null
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in mailman that allows a remote user to obtain administrative access to the list in certain situations.  Also, a valid list administrator can obtain the list password of a list subscriber.
A remote non-authorized user can gain access to the administrative interface of a list if the global password (located in the data/adm.pw file) is empty.  If it is empty, the administrative interface will accept any password as valid.

The software also allows the list administrator to obtain a user's list password.  Note that, by default, the password is mailed out in clear text every month, so the impact of this flaw may only be marginal.
Impact': A remote user can obtain administrative access to the list in certain cases.  An administrator can obtain a user's list password.
Solution: A fix is available.  For Conectiva Linux, see the Source Message for upgrade instructions.  For other operating systems, see the Vendor URL for information.

Title: Cyrus IMAP Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in the Cyrus IMAP e-mail server.  Remote users can cause the mail server to crash.
It is reported that a remote user with a PHP-based IMAP client can eventually cause the Cyrus mail server to hang, requiring a hard server reboot to return to normal operation.  This condition has reportedly been observed when using IMP and Jawmail webmail packages.
Impact': A remote user can cause the e-mail server to crash, requiring a reboot to return to normal operation.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Exploit Information) Re: Outlook Web Access Discloses Global Address List to Remote Users
Description:
Microsoft reported a vulnerability in Outlook Web Access that allows a remote user to search the global address list without being authenticated.
The back-end tier that actually performs the search of the global address list (GAL) via Outlook Web Access (OWA) can reportedly be accessed without authentication.  For more information on this vulnerability, see the Message History.

A user has provided exploit information:

To dump the complete GAL:
http://exchangesvr/exchange/finduser/fumsg.asp

If the site has more entries than the maximum defined or the default of 9999, 
you will get back an error message saying:

"This query would return too many addresses!"

In this case you need to create a html form with the action set to the

down the result set:

DN (Display Name)
FN (First Name)
LN (Last Name)
TL (Title)
AN (Alias)
CP (Company)
DP (Department)
OF (Office)
CY (City)

If you get redirected back to the logon page immediately, it means that you 
must establish a session with your browser first.  To do that, just browse to:
